1172706_12_ITEM15_P5_S0	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States of America).
1172706_12_ITEM15_P5_S1	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audits to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P5_S2	The Company is not required to have, nor were we engaged to perform, an audit of its internal control over financial reporting.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P5_S3	Our audits included consideration of internal control over financial reporting as a basis for designing audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P5_S4	Accordingly, we express no such opinion.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P6_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements, assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P6_S1	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P7_S0	In our opinion, the financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Invisa, Inc. as of December 31, 2010 and 2011, and the results of its operations and its cash flows for the years then ended in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P8_S0	Invisa, Inc., (the Company or Invisa ) is an enterprise that incorporates safety system technology and products into automated closure devices, such as parking gates, sliding gates, overhead garage doors and commercial overhead doors.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P8_S1	Invisa has also demonstrated production-ready prototypes of security products for the museum and other markets.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P8_S2	The Company is currently manufacturing and selling powered closure safety devices.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P9_S0	In preparing the financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America, management makes estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosures of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements, as well as the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P9_S1	Actual results could differ from those estimates.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P10_S0	The Company considers all highly liquid investments with a maturity of three months or less when purchased to be cash equivalents.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P10_S1	The Company maintains its cash and cash equivalents at a major commercial bank.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P11_S0	Accounts receivable are due primarily from companies in the gate manufacturing industry located throughout the United States and the United Kingdom.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P11_S1	Credit is extended based on an evaluation of the customers financial condition and, generally, collateral is not required.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P11_S2	Account balances are evaluated for collectability based on the condition of the customers credit including repayment history and trends and relative economic and business conditions.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P12_S0	Bad debts have not been significant.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P12_S1	During 2010 one customer comprised 11% of our sales.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P12_S2	During 2011 two customers comprised 37% of our sales.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P13_S0	The Company s inventory is stated at the lower of cost or market using an averaging method which approximates the first-in, first-out method.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P13_S1	The inventory has been evaluated for obsolescence and whether quantities on hand exceed quantities which can reasonably be expected to be sold in the near term.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P13_S2	Obsolete inventory is written off and excess quantities which are not expected to be sold in the near term are either written off or classified as a long-term asset.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P14_S0	Furniture, fixtures, and equipment are stated at cost and are depreciated on a straight-line basis over their estimated useful lives, principally five years.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P14_S1	Leasehold improvements are amortized over the term of the lease or the estimated useful lives, whichever is shorter.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P14_S2	Depreciation expense was $2,389 and $0 for 2010 and 2011 respectively.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P14_S3	At December 31, 2011, all furniture, fixtures and equipment was fully depreciated.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P15_S0	In general, the Company records revenue when persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, services have been rendered or product delivery has occurred, the sales price to the customer is fixed or determinable, and collectability is reasonably assured.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P16_S0	Product sales under fixed price arrangements are recognized as revenue upon shipment of product (when title transfers to the purchaser) and collectability is assured.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P17_S0	Other operating revenues relate to services and are recorded when services are complete.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P18_S0	Shipping and handling costs are included in cost of sales in the accompanying statements of operations.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P19_S0	Research and development costs consist of direct costs that are associated with the development of the Company s technology.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P19_S1	These costs are expensed as incurred.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P19_S2	During the years 2010 and 2011, the Company did not incur research and development expense.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P20_S0	The Company s policy is to expense advertising costs as incurred.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P21_S0	The Company warrants its products for ninety days.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P21_S1	Estimated warranty costs are recognized in the period product is shipped.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P21_S2	However, there have been no significant warranty costs incurred through December 31, 2011.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P21_S3	Accordingly, no warranty liability has been recognized for any period presented.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P22_S0	The Company follows ASC 740 Income Taxes for recording the provision for income taxes.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P23_S0	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are computed based upon the difference between the financial statement and income tax basis of assets and liabilities using the enacted marginal tax rate applicable when the related asset or liability is expected to be realized or settled.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P23_S1	Deferred income tax expenses or benefits are based on the changes in the asset or liability each period.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P23_S2	If available evidence suggests that it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized, a valuation allowance is required to reduce the deferred tax asset to the amount that is more likely than not to be realized.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P23_S3	Future changes in such valuation allowance are included in the provision for deferred income taxes in the period of change.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P24_S0	The Company follows ASC 740-10-05 Accounting for Uncertainty in Income Taxes .
1172706_12_ITEM15_P24_S1	The Interpretation prescribes a recognition threshold and a measurement attribute for the financial statement recognition and measurement of tax positions taken or expected to be taken in a tax return.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P24_S2	For those benefits to be recognized, a tax position must be more-likely-than-not to be sustained upon examination by taxing authorities.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P24_S3	The amount recognized is measured as the largest amount of benefit that is greater than 50 percent likely of being realized upon ultimate settlement.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P25_S0	The Company has adopted FASB ASC 820-10-50, Fair Value Measurements.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P25_S1	This guidance defines fair value, establishes a three-level valuation hierarchy for disclosures of fair value measurement and enhances disclosure requirements for fair value measures.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P25_S2	The three levels are defined as follows:
1172706_12_ITEM15_P26_S0	Level 1 inputs to the valuation methodology are quoted prices (unadjusted) for identical assets or liabilities in active markets.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P27_S0	Level 2 inputs to the valuation methodology include quoted prices for similar assets and liabilities in active markets, and inputs that are observable for the asset or liability, either directly or indirectly, for substantially the full term of the financial instrument.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P28_S0	Level 3 inputs to valuation methodology are unobservable and significant to the fair measurement.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P29_S0	The Company s financial instruments include cash and cash equivalents, accounts receivable, accounts payable and accrued expenses, notes payable and due to stockholders.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P29_S1	The carrying amounts of these financial instruments approximate their fair value, due to the short-term nature of these items and the use of market rates of interest.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P29_S2	The carrying value of the Company s long-term debt approximates fair value based on the terms and conditions of similar debt instruments.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P30_S0	The Company generally does not use derivative financial instruments to hedge exposures to cash-flow risks or market-risk that may affect the fair values of its financial instruments.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P30_S1	However, certain other financial instruments, such as warrants and embedded conversion features that are indexed to the Company s common stock, are classified as liabilities when either (a) the holder possesses rights to net cash settlement or (b) physical or net-share settlement is not within the control of the Company.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P30_S2	In such instances, net-cash settlement is assumed for financial accounting and reporting, even when the terms of the underlying contracts do not provide for net-cash settlement.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P30_S3	Such financial instruments are initially recorded at fair value and subsequently adjusted to fair value at the close of each reporting period.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P31_S0	The Company evaluates the recoverability of its long-lived assets or asset groups, annually; or whenever adverse events or changes in business climate indicate that the expected undiscounted future cash flows from the related asset may be less than previously anticipated.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P31_S1	If the net book value of the related asset exceeds the undiscounted future cash flows of the asset, the carrying amount would be reduced to the present value of its expected future cash flows and an impairment loss would be recognized.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P31_S2	There were no impairments in 2010 or 2011.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P32_S0	Basic earnings (loss) per share are calculated by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted average number of common shares outstanding for the period.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P32_S1	Diluted earnings (loss) per share is calculated by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted average number of common shares and dilutive common stock equivalents outstanding.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P32_S2	During periods in which the Company incurs losses common stock equivalents, if any, are not considered, as their effect would be anti dilutive.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P33_S0	At December 31, 2010 and 2011 the Preferred stock was convertible into 4,448,545 shares of common stock, which has not been considered in the calculation of diluted loss per share since the effect would be anti-dilutive.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P34_S0	The Company accounts for stock based compensation in accordance with ASC 718 Stock Compensation.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P34_S1	This Statement requires that the cost resulting from all share-based transactions be recorded in the financial statements.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P34_S2	The Statement establishes fair value as the measurement objective in accounting for share-based payment arrangements and requires all entities to apply a fair-value-based measurement in accounting for share-based payment transactions with employees.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P34_S3	The Statement also establishes fair value as the measurement objective for transactions in which an entity acquires goods or services from non-employees in share-based payment transactions.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P35_S0	In June 2011, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update 2011-05, Presentation of Comprehensive Income.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P35_S1	This Update amended the provisions of FASB ASC 220-10 by eliminating the option of reporting other comprehensive income in the statement of changes in stockholders equity.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P35_S2	Companies will have the option of presenting net income and other comprehensive income in a single, continuous statement of comprehensive income or presenting two separate but consecutive statements of net income and comprehensive income.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P35_S3	The new presentation requirements are effective for interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2011.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P35_S4	The adoption of this standard is not anticipated to have a material impact on our financial statements.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P36_S0	In September 2011, the FASB issued Accounting Standards Update 2011-08, Testing Goodwill for Impairment.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P36_S1	This Update amended the provisions of FASB ASC 350-20-35 by allowing an entity the option to make a qualitative evaluation about the likelihood of goodwill impairment to determine whether it should calculate the fair value of a reporting unit.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P36_S2	The amendments are effective for annual and interim goodwill impairment tests performed for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2011.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P36_S3	Early adoption is permitted, including for annual and interim goodwill impairment tests performed as of a date before September 15, 2011, if an entity s financial statements for the most recent annual or interim period have not yet been issued.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P36_S4	The adoption of this standard is not anticipated to have a material impact on our financial statements.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P37_S0	The Company does not believe that other recently issued accounting pronouncements will have a material impact on its financial statements.

1172706_12_ITEM15_P70_S0	ASC guidance requires that a deferred tax asset be reduced by a valuation allowance if, based on the weight of available evidence it is more likely than not (a likelihood of more than 50 percent) that some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P70_S1	The valuation allowance should be sufficient to reduce the deferred tax asset to the amount that is more likely than not to be realized.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P70_S2	As a result the Company recorded a valuation allowance with respect to all the Company s deferred tax assets.
1172706_12_ITEM15_P70_S3	The change in the valuation allowance was approximately $30,000 during 2011.

1172706_12_ITEM15_P207_S0	In connection with the Annual Report of Invisa, Inc. (the Company ) on Form 10-K for the period ending December 31, 2011 as filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on the date hereof (the Report ), I, Edmund C. King, Chief Financial Officer of the Company, certify, pursuant to 18 U.S.C. ss. 1350, as adopted pursuant to Section 906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, that to my knowledge:
1172706_12_ITEM15_P208_S0	The information contained in the Report fairly presents, in all material respects, the financial condition and result of operations of the Company.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P0_S0	Invisa, Inc. is a Nevada corporation that manufactures and sells a line of SmartGate brand safety sensors used in or with parking gates to protect life and property.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P1_S0	Parking gates are motorized barriers used to control the flow of vehicular traffic in areas such as parking facilities, vehicle storage facilities, tollbooths, and metered entry points for highways.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P2_S0	Our SmartGate sensors are based on presence sensing technology that we call InvisaShield.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P2_S1	While we believe that our InvisaShield technology may have additional applications for safety products, to date substantially all of our revenue has been derived from the sale of SmartGate sensors used in parking gates.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P3_S0	We acquired the InvisaShield presence-sensing technology in 2004.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P4_S0	Presence sensing is the repeatable detection of people and conductive objects within a certain perimeter of the sensor.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P4_S1	InvisaShield technology detects objects at a distance of typically less than one meter.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P4_S2	Invisa currently owns the patent and patent applications, as well as the sole rights to the InvisaShield technology in all markets worldwide.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P5_S0	Our offices are located at 1800 2nd Street, Suite 965, Sarasota, FL 34236, telephone (941) 870-3950.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P6_S0	Many products use presence-sensing technology; however, we believe that our InvisaShield technology is particularly suited to safety sensors for use in the parking gate market.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P6_S1	In 2011 and 2012, all of our revenues were derived from the sale of SmartGate safety sensors used with powered parking gates.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P6_S2	These gates typically have a power-operated barrier arm made of metal, wood or PVC.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P6_S3	This arm moves vertically between an open and a closed position.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P6_S4	Our device places an invisible presence-sensing field around the potentially dangerous barrier arm to detect people and vehicles in its path.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P6_S5	Our device signals the powered gate to trigger a predetermined response, such as stopping and reversing the barrier arm.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P6_S6	The retail price for our SmartGate sensors allow us to realize an acceptable gross profit margin, however, we continue to look for ways to decrease our cost of goods and increase our distribution to improve our profit margins.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P7_S0	We sell our safety products to manufacturers, dealers and end-users.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P7_S1	As part of our current sales efforts, we have attended trade shows and have continued our relationships with our customer list which comprises manufacturers, dealers and end users.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P7_S2	We also receive unsolicited orders either by telephone, fax or internet.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P7_S3	In addition, during fiscal year 2012, we have sought relationships with architectural engineering firms and municipalities that are implementing projects requiring parking barrier gates, such as municipal parking lots and airport reconstruction.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P8_S0	Although we do not maintain a full-time sales force, we do engage outside sales consultants.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P9_S0	In 2012, Ultimate Systems Solutions, LLC was our largest customer comprising 24% of our sales.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P9_S1	In 2011, SkiData, Inc. was our largest customer, also responsible for 24% of our product revenues.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P9_S2	Ultimate Systems Solutions, LLC in 2012 included a single large project and no assurance can be given that we will continue to sell products to Ultimate Systems at the same level once the project is complete.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P10_S0	InvisaShield technology uses electronic circuitry that emits, controls, and monitors changes in an invisible energy field.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P10_S1	The field is based, in part, upon low energy radio waves oscillating within a controlled frequency range.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P10_S2	The field that is monitored can be varied in sensitivity from a distance of approximately one meter to a centimeter or less, depending upon the selected application.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P10_S3	Circuitry constantly checks the field to test for the presence of people, vehicles or other conductive objects (objects that conduct electricity) that would disturb the monitored field.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P11_S0	We believe that the InvisaShield technology is a novel and proprietary way to provide presence sensing.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P12_S0	At the core of the technology is the ability to project a field or zone capable of detecting most conductive objects that enter the field.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P12_S1	The field is projected from a metallic substance, referred to as an antenna, which may consist of wire, self-adhesive metallic tape or other metallic items.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P12_S2	The technology allows flexibility in designing and locating the antenna.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P12_S3	This may offer unique opportunities to place presence-sensing fields where they can be used more efficiently or effectively.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P12_S4	This adaptability may permit the InvisaShield technology to perform non-contact presence-sensing tasks not currently possible with competing technologies and/or it may perform presence-sensing tasks similar to those performed by competing technologies, but in a more efficient, effective, and reliable manner.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P13_S0	InvisaShield technology does not depend upon lenses, beams or reflectors, which may require replacement, cleaning and aligning.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P13_S1	Its operating environment, including electronic noise, mechanical noise, temperature, dust, frost, snow, ice or other operating conditions, generally does not disrupt the non-intrusive, non-contact presence-sensing capability of our technology.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P14_S0	We have, in the past, sought to develop additional products based on our InvisaShield technology.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P14_S1	We have developed pre-production prototypes of safety products for various power doors such as slide-gates, commercial overhead doors, powered industrial doors (which are used in commercial, manufacturing and industrial facilities) and residential garage doors and pre-production prototypes of security products various applications in museums, retail and industrial.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P14_S2	We have indefinitely delayed such development projects; however, in 2011 we made certain modifications improving our line of antenna products.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P15_S0	Competing Technologies - The presence-sensing business is highly competitive, consisting of numerous manufacturers of presence-sensing products based on various technologies, including infrared, ultrasonic, laser, microwave, and similar technologies.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P15_S1	For the most part, these technologies have been in use for a number of years and, in many cases, may not be proprietary.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P15_S2	Our competitors provide a variety of presence-sensing and other safety and security alternatives such as motion detectors, CCTV-based movement detection systems, infrared and visible light beam detectors, light curtains, on/off switching mats and pads, tape switches, contact edges, as well as others.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P16_S0	In the safety and/or security sectors we compete with many companies, including MillerEdge, Stanley, Optex, Napco, Pelco, and DMP, along with other large and well-established firms such as Honeywell, Tyco, General Electric, Bosch, and Siemens.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P16_S1	Many of our competitors have substantially greater development, technical, marketing, sales and financial capabilities than we have.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P16_S2	As a result of these factors, competitors and potential competitors may be able to respond more quickly to new or emerging technologies and changes in customer requirements and/or to devote greater resources to the development, promotion and sale of their products and services than we can.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P17_S0	No. 7,187,282 issued on March 6, 2007.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P17_S1	In addition, we have filed for two patents (as PCT, or Patent Cooperation Treaty filings), one provisional patent application and have one application pending, all of which cover improvements to the InvisaShield technology.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P18_S0	We have a trademark on the trade name SmartGate which we use in our safety products category.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P18_S1	We have filed trademark applications for the following: Invisa , InvisaShield and the tagline Safe.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P18_S2	We believe that our patent and trademark position will be useful in our efforts to protect our perceived competitive advantages.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P19_S0	All components and parts are modified or manufactured to our specifications by third parties or are otherwise generally available as off-the-shelf materials.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P19_S1	Our products have a number of components including proprietary electronic circuitry manufactured to our specifications by third party manufacturers and a standard power supply available in the marketplace.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P20_S0	The antenna is standard wire, tape or other metallic materials, which can generally be purchased in bulk.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P20_S1	Whenever possible, we use fixed price manufacturing for our electronic circuitry, placing the responsibility for component supply on the manufacturer.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P20_S2	We believe that there are multiple manufacturers and suppliers for each component and that adequate components and materials will be available to support our business plan.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P20_S3	We perform some final assembly and predetermined quality control procedures in our facility using contractors, including contract piece work in connection with the assembly when needed.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P20_S4	All shipping is done directly from our facility.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P21_S0	The Federal Communications Commission regulates the use of radio frequency or RF , such as that used by our safety products.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P21_S1	We currently have FCC Certification for our product.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P21_S2	We will endeavor to continue satisfying all requirements of the FCC to maintain our FCC Certification.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P22_S0	On March 1, 2001, Underwriters Laboratory (UL) implemented a new safety standard for the powered gate, door and window industry.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P22_S1	This rule, UL-325, while not a governmental regulation, is considered an indication of reasonable safety for powered gates, doors and windows, and is a requirement for UL certification for certain powered gate, door and window operators.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P22_S2	Gate and operator manufacturers that rely upon UL certification or consider UL certification important for components most likely will require that our products be UL certified before incorporating our products as original equipment.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P22_S3	We do not have a UL certification and the absence of UL certification for our products may represent a sales or marketing barrier in certain market categories and to certain customers.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P23_S0	Our products have also earned the Conformit Europ enne marking (also known as CE mark) which is a mandatory conformity mark placed on many products used in the single market in the European Economic Area.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P23_S1	The CE mark certifies that a product has met EU consumer safety, health or environmental requirements.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P23_S2	This marking is mandatory for sales of products in approximately 27 European countries but is usually preferred by customers whether or not required in their respective countries.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P24_S0	In addition to gaining the CE mark, our products are now RoHS compliant and have been since late 2008.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P25_S0	The directive on the restriction of the use of certain hazardous substances in electrical and electronic equipment 2002/95/EC; commonly referred to as the Restriction of Hazardous Substances Directive or RoHS) was adopted in February 2003 by the European Union and took effect in July 2006.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P25_S1	This directive restricts the use of six hazardous materials (lead, mercury, cadmium, hexavalent chromium, polybrominated biphenyls and polybrominated diphenyl ether), in the manufacture of various types of electronic and electrical equipment.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P25_S2	By complying with the RoHS directive, our customers are assured that our products are free of these hazardous substances.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P26_S0	Our safety products are sold with a 90-day limited warranty against manufactures parts and defects.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P26_S1	We have had no significant claims expensed under the warranty in 2011 or 2012.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P27_S0	We have no full time employees.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P27_S1	Our Chief Executive Officer, who is currently our Chief Financial Officer, serves in both capacities on a part-time consulting basis.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P27_S2	We support our operations by using consultants and third party contract piece workers as required .
1172706_13_ITEM1_P28_S0	We are not conducting any research and development with respect to our technology at this time.
1172706_13_ITEM1_P28_S1	Therefore, during the years ended December 31, 2011 and 2012 we incurred no research and development expenses.

1172706_13_ITEM1A_P15_S3	Any infringement, misappropriation or independent development could cause us to cease operations.
1172706_13_ITEM1A_P16_S0	We have issued patents and have filed patent applications with respect to various aspects of our technology.
1172706_13_ITEM1A_P16_S1	The pending patent applications may not be issued to us, and if issued, may not protect our intellectual property from competition, which could seek to design around or invalidate these patents.
1172706_13_ITEM1A_P16_S2	Our failure to adequately protect our proprietary rights in our products, services and technology could harm our business by making it easier for our competitors to duplicate our services.
1172706_13_ITEM1A_P16_S3	We may have to resort to litigation to enforce our intellectual property rights, protect our trade secrets, determine the validity and scope of the proprietary rights of others, or defend ourselves from claims of infringement, invalidity or unenforceability.
1172706_13_ITEM1A_P16_S4	Litigation may be expensive and divert resources even if we win.
1172706_13_ITEM1A_P16_S5	This could adversely affect our business, financial condition and operating results such that it could cause us to reduce or cease operations.
1172706_13_ITEM1A_P17_S0	Other parties may assert that our technology infringes on their Intellectual property rights, which could divert management time and resources and possibly force our Company to redesign our technology.
1172706_13_ITEM1A_P18_S0	Technology-based companies, such as ours, have the potential to be involved in litigation related to allegations of patent infringement.
1172706_13_ITEM1A_P18_S1	Although we have no knowledge of any such claims, from time to time, third parties may assert patent, copyright and other intellectual property rights to technologies that are important to us.
1172706_13_ITEM1A_P18_S2	While there currently are no outstanding infringement claims pending by or against us, we cannot assure you that third parties will not assert infringement claims against us in the future, that assertion by such parties will not result in costly litigation, or that they will not prevail in any such litigation.
1172706_13_ITEM1A_P18_S3	In addition, we cannot assure you that we will be able to license any valid and infringed patents from third parties on commercially reasonable terms or, alternatively, be able to redesign products on a cost-effective basis to avoid infringement.
1172706_13_ITEM1A_P18_S4	Any infringement claim or other litigation against or by us could have a material adverse effect on us and could cause us to reduce or cease operations.
1172706_13_ITEM1A_P19_S0	We may not be able to keep up with rapid technological changes, which could render our products less competitive or obsolete.
1172706_13_ITEM1A_P20_S0	Changes in technology, changes in customer requirements and preferences, introduction of products and services embodying new or different technologies and the emergence of new industry standards and practices could render our existing technology and products less competitive or obsolete.
1172706_13_ITEM1A_P20_S1	Our future success will depend on our ability to enhance and improve the responsiveness, functionality, accessibility and features of our technology and products.
1172706_13_ITEM1A_P20_S2	We expect that our marketplace will require extensive technological upgrades and enhancements to accommodate many of the new products and services that we anticipate will be added to our marketplace.
1172706_13_ITEM1A_P20_S3	We cannot assure you that we will be able to expand and upgrade our technology and systems, or successfully integrate new technologies or systems we develop in the future, to accommodate such increases in a timely manner.
1172706_13_ITEM1A_P21_S0	We may not be able to increase sales or if we succeed in increasing sales and revenue, we may not be able to effectively manage the growth necessary to execute our business plan, which could adversely affect the quality of our operations and our costs.
1172706_13_ITEM1A_P22_S0	In order to successfully execute our business plan, we must significantly increase our sales and revenue.
1172706_13_ITEM1A_P22_S1	Additionally, we will need to increase the number of strategic partners, manufacturers, dealers, distributors and customers that use our products.
1172706_13_ITEM1A_P22_S2	Lack of growth in sales and revenue will require that we continue to access financing which will subject us to the risks attendant thereto.
1172706_13_ITEM1A_P22_S3	On the other hand, if we succeed in increasing sales and revenue, the resulting growth will place significant strain on our systems and resources.
1172706_13_ITEM1A_P22_S4	In the event of growth, we may not be able to maintain the quality of our operations, control our costs, continue complying with all applicable regulations and expand our internal management, technical information and accounting systems in order to support our desired growth.
1172706_13_ITEM1A_P22_S5	We cannot be sure that we will manage our growth effectively, and our failure to do so could cause us to reduce or cease operations.

1172706_13_ITEM9A_P0_S0	The Company maintains disclosure controls and procedures as defined in Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (the Exchange Act ), that are designed to ensure that information required to be disclosed by us in reports we file or submit under the Exchange Act is recorded, processed, summarized and reported within the time periods specified in the SEC s rules and forms, and that such information is accumulated and communicated to our management, including our Acting President, Chief Financial Officer, and Board of Directors, as appropriate, to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure.
1172706_13_ITEM9A_P0_S1	In designing and evaluating our disclosure controls and procedures, management recognizes that disclosure controls and procedures, no matter how well conceived and operated, can provide only reasonable assurance of achieving the desired objectives, and we necessarily are required to apply our judgment in evaluating the cost-benefit relationship of possible disclosure controls and procedures.
1172706_13_ITEM9A_P1_S0	Our management, including our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, evaluated the effectiveness of the design and operation of our disclosure controls and procedures as of December 31, 2012 and concluded that our disclosure controls and procedures were effective as of December 31, 2012.
1172706_13_ITEM9A_P2_S0	The Company s management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting as defined in Rule 13a-15(f) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
1172706_13_ITEM9A_P2_S1	The Company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with United States generally accepted accounting principles.
1172706_13_ITEM9A_P2_S2	Internal control over financial reporting includes policies and procedures that (i) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the Company; (ii) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with United States generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the Company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the Company; and (iii) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisitions, use or disposition of the Company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
1172706_13_ITEM9A_P3_S0	Management assessed the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2012.
1172706_13_ITEM9A_P3_S1	In making this assessment, management used the criteria set forth by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission ( COSO ) in Internal Control-Integrated Framework.
1172706_13_ITEM9A_P3_S2	Based on this assessment, and on those criteria, management concluded that the Company s internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December 31, 2012.
1172706_13_ITEM9A_P4_S0	This annual report does not include an attestation report of the Company s registered public accounting firm regarding internal control over financial reporting.
1172706_13_ITEM9A_P4_S1	Management s report was not subject to attestation by the Company s registered public accounting firm pursuant to rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission that permit the Company to provide only management s report in this annual report.

1172706_13_ITEM11_P0_S0	This Compensation Discussion and Analysis is intended to describe the material factors underlying the compensation policies and decisions of the Company with regard to compensation paid to our executive officers in 2011 and 2012.
1172706_13_ITEM11_P1_S0	The Compensation Committee oversees the Company s executive compensation in accordance with its Charter and recommends to the Board of Directors compensation for the named executive officers.
1172706_13_ITEM11_P1_S1	The Compensation Committee receives input and recommendations when requested from our executive officers.
1172706_13_ITEM11_P2_S0	During 2011 two additional executive officers (John Zappala, as President; Elizabeth Henson, as Vice President of Operations) were authorized.
1172706_13_ITEM11_P2_S1	Mr. Edmund King, our CEO and CFO, does not have a written employment agreement and works on a part-time basis for the Company.
1172706_13_ITEM11_P2_S2	Mr. King received no salary or other cash compensation during fiscal 2011 or 2012.

1172706_13_ITEM11_P2_S6	In addition, Mr. Zappala, according to his contract, was granted 100,000 shares to be received upon completion and approval of a market survey and Ms. Henson received Common stock grants totaling 30,000 shares for service in 2011.
1172706_13_ITEM11_P3_S0	Our compensation philosophy for our executive officers has been shaped by our lack of long-term financing and our severe shortage of operating capital.
1172706_13_ITEM11_P3_S1	Accordingly, our compensation decisions and particularly our approach to allocating compensation between cash and non-cash elements of the compensation package reflect our goal to preserve cash whenever possible.
1172706_13_ITEM11_P4_S0	In making our compensation decisions, we strive to be aware of the level of compensation which is paid to executive officers of various companies that we consider to be comparable to us in size.
1172706_13_ITEM11_P4_S1	Our goal is for the compensation paid to our named executive officers to be at or below the fiftieth percentile of the companies that we have identified as being comparable companies.
1172706_13_ITEM11_P5_S0	Mr. King did not receive any base salary in fiscal 2011 or 2012; however, an amount of $36,000 has been charged to operations and credited to additional paid in capital in each of these years.
1172706_13_ITEM11_P6_S0	No Options were granted in fiscal years 2011 or 2012.
1172706_13_ITEM11_P7_S0	Consistent with our philosophy to preserve cash, we have sought to limit perquisites.
1172706_13_ITEM11_P7_S1	Perquisites paid to our named executive officers are discussed as footnotes to the following Summary Compensation Table.
1172706_13_ITEM11_P8_S0	Our current policy for paying medical and dental insurance is not to pay insurance premiums.
1172706_13_ITEM11_P8_S1	Our policy is not to pay for life insurance, long-term and short-term disability insurances and accidental death and dismemberment insurance.
1172706_13_ITEM11_P8_S2	Our policy with regard to unused vacation for our executive group is to pay at the base salary rate for vacation not used during the calendar year of termination.

1172706_13_ITEM11_P11_S0	We have five stock plans as listed below:
1172706_13_ITEM11_P12_S0	All of the Plans have been approved by the Board of Directors and all, except for the 2006 Plan, have been approved by the Shareholders.
1172706_13_ITEM11_P12_S1	All of the plans authorize awards of incentive stock options or non-qualified stock options to employees, directors, and consultants of our company and affiliates.
1172706_13_ITEM11_P12_S2	The purposes of the Plans are as follows: to encourage and enable employees, directors, and consultants to acquire a proprietary interest in the growth and performance of our company; to generate an increased incentive for key employees and directors to contribute to our future success and prosperity, thus enhancing the value of our company for the benefit of our stockholders; and to enhance the ability of our company to attract and retain key employees and directors who are essential to progress, growth, and profitability.
1172706_13_ITEM11_P13_S0	The Plans are administered by the Compensation Committee of our Board (the Administrator ).
1172706_13_ITEM11_P13_S1	All members of our Compensation Committee are non-employee directors and outside directors, as defined in the Plans.
1172706_13_ITEM11_P14_S0	Subject to the limitations set forth in the Plans, the administrator has the authority to grant options, to determine the purchase price of the shares of our common stock covered by each option, to establish the term of each option, to determine the number of shares of our common stock to be covered by each option, to establish vesting schedules, to designate options as incentive stock options or non-qualified stock options, and to determine the persons to whom grants are to be made.
1172706_13_ITEM11_P15_S0	The Administrator establishes the option exercise price, which in the case of incentive stock options, must be at least the market price (as such term is defined in the Plans) of our common stock on the date of the grant or, with respect to optionees who own at least 10% of the total combined voting power of all classes of our stock (a 10% Stockholder ), 110% of the market price on the date of the grant.
1172706_13_ITEM11_P16_S0	Options granted under the Plans are generally not transferable by the optionee except by will or the laws of descent and distribution, or pursuant to written agreement approved by the administrator relating to any non-qualified stock options in any manner authorized under applicable law.
1172706_13_ITEM11_P17_S0	Except as provided in the applicable stock option agreement, options must be exercised within 90 days of termination for any reason other than disability, retirement, or death, within one year of termination by disability or retirement, or by a designated beneficiary within two years of death.
1172706_13_ITEM11_P18_S0	Except as provided to the contrary in the option agreement, options granted under the Plans vest in one-third annual increments, beginning on the grant date of the option.
1172706_13_ITEM11_P18_S1	In no event may an incentive stock option be granted more than 10 years from the effective date of the plan or be exercised after either the expiration of 10 years from the grant date, or five years from the grant date in the case of a 10% Stockholder.
1172706_13_ITEM11_P19_S0	Incentive stock options may not vest for the first time with the respect to any optionee in a calendar year with a market price exceeding $100,000.
1172706_13_ITEM11_P19_S1	Any option grants that exceed that amount shall be automatically treated as non-statutory stock options.
1172706_13_ITEM11_P20_S0	The Plans may be suspended, terminated, modified, or amended by our board, but no such suspension, termination, modification, or amendment may adversely affect the terms of any option previously granted without the consent of the affected optionee, and any amendment will be subject to stockholder approval to the extent required by applicable law, rules, or regulations.

1172706_13_ITEM15_P9_S0	In our opinion, the financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Invisa, Inc. as of December 31, 2011 and 2012, and the results of its operations and its cash flows for the years then ended in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P10_S0	Invisa, Inc., (the Company or Invisa ) is an enterprise that incorporates safety system technology and products into automated closure devices, such as parking gates, sliding gates, overhead garage doors and commercial overhead doors.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P10_S1	Invisa has also demonstrated production-ready prototypes of security products for the museum and other markets.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P10_S2	The Company is currently manufacturing and selling powered closure safety devices.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P11_S0	In preparing the financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America, management makes estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosures of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements, as well as the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P11_S1	Actual results could differ from those estimates.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P12_S0	The Company considers all highly liquid investments with a maturity of three months or less when purchased to be cash equivalents.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P12_S1	The Company maintains its cash and cash equivalents at a major commercial bank.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P13_S0	Accounts receivable are due primarily from companies in the gate manufacturing industry primarily located throughout the United States.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P13_S1	Credit is extended based on an evaluation of the customers financial condition and, generally, collateral is not required.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P13_S2	Account balances are evaluated for collectability based on the condition of the customers credit including repayment history and trends and relative economic and business conditions.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P14_S0	Bad debts have not been significant.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P14_S1	During 2011 two customers comprised 37% of our sales.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P14_S2	During 2012 three customers comprised 49% of our sales.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P15_S0	The Company s inventory is stated at the lower of cost or market using an averaging method which approximates the first-in, first-out method.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P15_S1	The inventory has been evaluated for obsolescence and whether quantities on hand exceed quantities which can reasonably be expected to be sold in the near term.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P15_S2	Obsolete inventory is written off and excess quantities which are not expected to be sold in the near term are either written off or classified as a long-term asset.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P16_S0	Furniture, fixtures, and equipment are stated at cost and are depreciated on a straight-line basis over their estimated useful lives, principally five years.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P16_S1	Leasehold improvements are amortized over the term of the lease or the estimated useful lives, whichever is shorter.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P16_S2	Depreciation expense was $0 for 2011 and 2012.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P16_S3	At December 31, 2012, all furniture, fixtures and equipment was fully depreciated.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P17_S0	In general, the Company records revenue when persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, services have been rendered or product delivery has occurred, the sales price to the customer is fixed or determinable, and collectability is reasonably assured.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P18_S0	Product sales under fixed price arrangements are recognized as revenue upon shipment of product (when title transfers to the purchaser) and collectability is assured.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P19_S0	Other operating revenues relate to services and are recorded when services are complete.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P20_S0	Shipping and handling costs are included in cost of sales in the accompanying statements of operations.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P21_S0	Research and development costs consist of direct costs that are associated with the development of the Company s technology.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P21_S1	These costs are expensed as incurred.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P21_S2	During the years 2011 and 2012, the Company did not incur research and development expense.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P22_S0	The Company s policy is to expense advertising costs as incurred.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P23_S0	The Company warrants its products for ninety days.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P23_S1	Estimated warranty costs are recognized in the period product is shipped.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P23_S2	However, there have been no significant warranty costs incurred through December 31, 2012.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P23_S3	Accordingly, no warranty liability has been recognized for any period presented.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P24_S0	The Company follows ASC 740 Income Taxes for recording the provision for income taxes.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P25_S0	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are computed based upon the difference between the financial statement and income tax basis of assets and liabilities using the enacted marginal tax rate applicable when the related asset or liability is expected to be realized or settled.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P25_S1	Deferred income tax expenses or benefits are based on the changes in the asset or liability each period.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P25_S2	If available evidence suggests that it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized, a valuation allowance is required to reduce the deferred tax asset to the amount that is more likely than not to be realized.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P25_S3	Future changes in such valuation allowance are included in the provision for deferred income taxes in the period of change.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P26_S0	The Company follows ASC 740-10-05 Accounting for Uncertainty in Income Taxes .
1172706_13_ITEM15_P26_S1	The Interpretation prescribes a recognition threshold and a measurement attribute for the financial statement recognition and measurement of tax positions taken or expected to be taken in a tax return.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P26_S2	For those benefits to be recognized, a tax position must be more-likely-than-not to be sustained upon examination by taxing authorities.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P26_S3	The amount recognized is measured as the largest amount of benefit that is greater than 50 percent likely of being realized upon ultimate settlement.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P27_S0	The Company has adopted FASB ASC 820-10-50, Fair Value Measurements.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P27_S1	This guidance defines fair value, establishes a three-level valuation hierarchy for disclosures of fair value measurement and enhances disclosure requirements for fair value measures.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P27_S2	The three levels are defined as follows:
1172706_13_ITEM15_P28_S0	Level 1 inputs to the valuation methodology are quoted prices (unadjusted) for identical assets or liabilities in active markets.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P29_S0	Level 2 inputs to the valuation methodology include quoted prices for similar assets and liabilities in active markets, and inputs that are observable for the asset or liability, either directly or indirectly, for substantially the full term of the financial instrument.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P30_S0	Level 3 inputs to valuation methodology are unobservable and significant to the fair measurement.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P31_S0	The Company s financial instruments include cash and cash equivalents, accounts receivable, accounts payable and accrued expenses, notes payable and due to stockholders.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P31_S1	The carrying amounts of these financial instruments approximate their fair value, due to the short-term nature of these items and the use of market rates of interest.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P31_S2	The carrying value of the Company s long-term debt approximates fair value based on the terms and conditions of similar debt instruments.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P32_S0	The Company generally does not use derivative financial instruments to hedge exposures to cash-flow risks or market-risk that may affect the fair values of its financial instruments.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P32_S1	However, certain other financial instruments, such as warrants and embedded conversion features that are indexed to the Company s common stock, are classified as liabilities when either (a) the holder possesses rights to net cash settlement or (b) physical or net-share settlement is not within the control of the Company.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P32_S2	In such instances, net-cash settlement is assumed for financial accounting and reporting, even when the terms of the underlying contracts do not provide for net-cash settlement.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P32_S3	Such financial instruments are initially recorded at fair value and subsequently adjusted to fair value at the close of each reporting period.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P33_S0	The Company evaluates the recoverability of its long-lived assets or asset groups, annually; or whenever adverse events or changes in business climate indicate that the expected undiscounted future cash flows from the related asset may be less than previously anticipated.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P33_S1	If the net book value of the related asset exceeds the undiscounted future cash flows of the asset, the carrying amount would be reduced to the present value of its expected future cash flows and an impairment loss would be recognized.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P33_S2	There were no impairments in 2011 or 2012.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P34_S0	Basic earnings (loss) per share are calculated by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted average number of common shares outstanding for the period.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P34_S1	Diluted earnings (loss) per share is calculated by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted average number of common shares and dilutive common stock equivalents outstanding.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P34_S2	During periods in which the Company incurs losses common stock equivalents, if any, are not considered, as their effect would be anti dilutive.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P35_S0	At December 31, 2011 and 2012 the Preferred stock was convertible into 4,448,545 shares of common stock, which has not been considered in the calculation of diluted loss per share since the effect would be anti-dilutive.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P36_S0	The Company accounts for stock based compensation in accordance with ASC 718 Stock Compensation.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P36_S1	This Statement requires that the cost resulting from all share-based transactions be recorded in the financial statements.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P36_S2	The Statement establishes fair value as the measurement objective in accounting for share-based payment arrangements and requires all entities to apply a fair-value-based measurement in accounting for share-based payment transactions with employees.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P36_S3	The Statement also establishes fair value as the measurement objective for transactions in which an entity acquires goods or services from non-employees in share-based payment transactions.

1172706_13_ITEM15_P70_S0	ASC guidance requires that a deferred tax asset be reduced by a valuation allowance if, based on the weight of available evidence it is more likely than not (a likelihood of more than 50 percent) that some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized.
1172706_13_ITEM15_P70_S1	The valuation allowance should be sufficient to reduce the deferred tax asset to the amount that is more likely than not to be realized.

1172706_13_ITEM15_P197_S0	In connection with the Annual Report of Invisa, Inc. (the Company or Invisa ) on Form 10-K for the period ending December 31, 2012 as filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on the date hereof (the Report ), I, Edmund C. King, Chief Financial Officer of the Company, certify, pursuant to 18 U.S.C. Section 1350, as adopted pursuant to Section 906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, that to my knowledge:
1172706_13_ITEM15_P198_S0	The information contained in the Report fairly presents, in all material respects, the financial condition and result of operations of the Company.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P0_S0	Invisa, Inc. is a Nevada corporation that manufactures and sells a line of SmartGate brand safety sensors used in or with parking gates to protect life and property.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P1_S0	Parking gates are motorized barriers used to control the flow of vehicular traffic in areas such as parking facilities, vehicle storage facilities, tollbooths, and metered entry points for highways.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P2_S0	Our SmartGate sensors are based on presence sensing technology that we call InvisaShield.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P2_S1	While we believe that our InvisaShield technology may have additional applications for safety products, to date substantially all of our revenue has been derived from the sale of SmartGate sensors used in parking gates.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P3_S0	We acquired the InvisaShield presence-sensing technology in 2004.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P4_S0	Presence sensing is the repeatable detection of people and conductive objects within a certain perimeter of the sensor.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P4_S1	InvisaShield technology detects objects at a distance of typically less than one meter.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P4_S2	Invisa currently owns the patent and patent applications, as well as the sole rights to the InvisaShield technology in all markets worldwide.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P5_S0	Our offices are located at 1800 2nd Street, Suite 965, Sarasota, FL 34236, telephone (941) 870-3950.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P6_S0	Many products use presence-sensing technology; however, we believe that our InvisaShield technology is particularly suited to safety sensors for use in the parking gate market.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P6_S1	In 2012 and 2013, all of our revenues were derived from the sale of SmartGate safety sensors used with powered parking gates.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P6_S2	These gates typically have a power-operated barrier arm made of metal, wood or PVC.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P6_S3	This arm moves vertically between an open and a closed position.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P6_S4	Our device places an invisible presence-sensing field around the potentially dangerous barrier arm to detect people and vehicles in its path.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P6_S5	Our device signals the powered gate to trigger a predetermined response, such as stopping and reversing the barrier arm.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P6_S6	The retail price for our SmartGate sensors allow us to realize an acceptable gross profit margin, however, we continue to look for ways to decrease our cost of goods and increase our distribution to improve our profit margins.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P7_S0	We sell our safety products to manufacturers, dealers and end-users.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P7_S1	As part of our current sales efforts, we have attended trade shows and have continued our relationships with our customer list which comprises manufacturers, dealers and end users.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P7_S2	We also receive unsolicited orders either by telephone, fax or internet.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P7_S3	In addition, we have sought relationships with architectural engineering firms and municipalities that are implementing projects requiring parking barrier gates, such as municipal parking lots and airport reconstruction.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P8_S0	Although we do not maintain a full-time sales force, we do engage outside sales consultants.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P9_S0	In 2013, Electro Automation, Ltd. was our largest customer comprising 27% of our sales.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P9_S1	In 2012, Ultimate Systems Solutions, LLC was our largest customer comprising 24% of our sales.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P10_S0	InvisaShield technology uses electronic circuitry that emits, controls, and monitors changes in an invisible energy field.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P10_S1	The field is based, in part, upon low energy radio waves oscillating within a controlled frequency range.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P10_S2	The field that is monitored can be varied in sensitivity from a distance of approximately one meter to a centimeter or less, depending upon the selected application.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P10_S3	Circuitry constantly checks the field to test for the presence of people, vehicles or other conductive objects (objects that conduct electricity) that would disturb the monitored field.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P11_S0	We believe that the InvisaShield technology is a novel and proprietary way to provide presence sensing.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P12_S0	At the core of the technology is the ability to project a field or zone capable of detecting most conductive objects that enter the field.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P12_S1	The field is projected from a metallic substance, referred to as an antenna, which may consist of wire, self-adhesive metallic tape or other metallic items.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P12_S2	The technology allows flexibility in designing and locating the antenna.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P12_S3	This may offer unique opportunities to place presence-sensing fields where they can be used more efficiently or effectively.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P12_S4	This adaptability may permit the InvisaShield technology to perform non-contact presence-sensing tasks not currently possible with competing technologies and/or it may perform presence-sensing tasks similar to those performed by competing technologies, but in a more efficient, effective, and reliable manner.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P13_S0	InvisaShield technology does not depend upon lenses, beams or reflectors, which may require replacement, cleaning and aligning.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P13_S1	Its operating environment, including electronic noise, mechanical noise, temperature, dust, frost, snow, ice or other operating conditions, generally does not disrupt the non-intrusive, non-contact presence-sensing capability of our technology.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P14_S0	We have, in the past, sought to develop additional products based on our InvisaShield technology.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P14_S1	We have developed pre-production prototypes of safety products for various power doors such as slide-gates, commercial overhead doors, powered industrial doors (which are used in commercial, manufacturing and industrial facilities) and residential garage doors and pre-production prototypes of security products various applications in museums, retail and industrial.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P14_S2	We have indefinitely delayed such development projects.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P15_S0	Competing Technologies - The presence-sensing business is highly competitive, consisting of numerous manufacturers of presence-sensing products based on various technologies, including infrared, ultrasonic, laser, microwave, and similar technologies.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P15_S1	For the most part, these technologies have been in use for a number of years and, in many cases, may not be proprietary.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P15_S2	Our competitors provide a variety of presence-sensing and other safety and security alternatives such as motion detectors, CCTV-based movement detection systems, infrared and visible light beam detectors, light curtains, on/off switching mats and pads, tape switches, contact edges, as well as others.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P16_S0	In the safety and/or security sectors we compete with many companies, including MillerEdge, Stanley, Optex, Napco, Pelco, and DMP, along with other large and well-established firms such as Honeywell, Tyco, General Electric, Bosch, and Siemens.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P16_S1	Many of our competitors have substantially greater development, technical, marketing, sales and financial capabilities than we have.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P16_S2	As a result of these factors, competitors and potential competitors may be able to respond more quickly to new or emerging technologies and changes in customer requirements and/or to devote greater resources to the development, promotion and sale of their products and services than we can.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P17_S0	Trademarks - We have a trademark on the trade name SmartGate which we use in our safety products category.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P17_S1	We have filed trademark applications for the following: Invisa , InvisaShield and the tagline Safe.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P17_S2	We believe that our patent and trademark position will be useful in our efforts to protect our perceived competitive advantages.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P18_S0	All components and parts are modified or manufactured to our specifications by third parties or are otherwise generally available as off-the-shelf materials.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P18_S1	Our products have a number of components including proprietary electronic circuitry manufactured to our specifications by third party manufacturers and a standard power supply available in the marketplace.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P19_S0	The antenna is standard wire, tape or other metallic materials, which can generally be purchased in bulk.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P19_S1	Whenever possible, we use fixed price manufacturing for our electronic circuitry, placing the responsibility for component supply on the manufacturer.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P19_S2	We believe that there are multiple manufacturers and suppliers for each component and that adequate components and materials will be available to support our business plan.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P19_S3	We perform some final assembly and predetermined quality control procedures in our facility using contractors, including contract piece work in connection with the assembly when needed.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P19_S4	All shipping is done directly from our facility.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P20_S0	The Federal Communications Commission regulates the use of radio frequency or RF , such as that used by our safety products.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P20_S1	We currently have FCC Certification for our product.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P20_S2	We will endeavor to continue satisfying all requirements of the FCC to maintain our FCC Certification.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P21_S0	On March 1, 2001, Underwriters Laboratory (UL) implemented a new safety standard for the powered gate, door and window industry.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P21_S1	This rule, UL-325, while not a governmental regulation, is considered an indication of reasonable safety for powered gates, doors and windows, and is a requirement for UL certification for certain powered gate, door and window operators.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P21_S2	Gate and operator manufacturers that rely upon UL certification or consider UL certification important for components most likely will require that our products be UL certified before incorporating our products as original equipment.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P21_S3	We do not have a UL certification and the absence of UL certification for our products may represent a sales or marketing barrier in certain market categories and to certain customers.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P22_S0	Our products have also earned the Conformit Europ enne marking (also known as CE mark) which is a mandatory conformity mark placed on many products used in the single market in the European Economic Area.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P22_S1	The CE mark certifies that a product has met EU consumer safety, health or environmental requirements.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P22_S2	This marking is mandatory for sales of products in approximately 27 European countries but is usually preferred by customers whether or not required in their respective countries.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P23_S0	In addition to gaining the CE mark, our products are now RoHS compliant and have been since late 2008.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P24_S0	The directive on the restriction of the use of certain hazardous substances in electrical and electronic equipment 2002/95/EC; commonly referred to as the Restriction of Hazardous Substances Directive or RoHS) was adopted in February 2003 by the European Union and took effect in July 2006.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P24_S1	This directive restricts the use of six hazardous materials (lead, mercury, cadmium, hexavalent chromium, polybrominated biphenyls and polybrominated diphenyl ether), in the manufacture of various types of electronic and electrical equipment.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P24_S2	By complying with the RoHS directive, our customers are assured that our products are free of these hazardous substances.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P25_S0	Our safety products are sold with a 90-day limited warranty against manufactures parts and defects.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P25_S1	We have had no significant claims expensed under the warranty in 2012 or 2013.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P26_S0	We have no full time employees.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P26_S1	Our Chief Executive Officer, who is also our Chief Financial Officer, serves in both capacities on a part-time consulting basis.
1172706_14_ITEM1_P26_S2	We support our operations by using consultants and third party contract piece workers as required .

1172706_14_ITEM7_P13_S0	In preparing the financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America, management makes estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosures of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements, as well as the reported amounts of revenues and expense during the reporting period.
1172706_14_ITEM7_P13_S1	Actual results could differ from those estimates.
1172706_14_ITEM7_P14_S0	In general, the Company records revenue when persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, services have been rendered or product delivery has occurred, the sales price to the customer is fixed or determinable, and collectability is reasonably assured.
1172706_14_ITEM7_P15_S0	Product sales under fixed price arrangements are recognized as revenue upon shipment of product (when title transfers to the purchaser) and collectability is assured.
1172706_14_ITEM7_P16_S0	Other operating revenues relate to services and are recorded when services are complete.

1172706_14_ITEM7_P17_S1	This Statement requires that the cost resulting from all share-based transactions be recorded in the financial statements.
1172706_14_ITEM7_P17_S2	The Statement establishes fair value as the measurement objective in accounting for share-based payment arrangements and requires all entities to apply a fair-value-based measurement in accounting for share-based payment transactions with employees.
1172706_14_ITEM7_P17_S3	The Statement also establishes fair value as the measurement objective for transactions in which an entity acquires goods or services from non-employees in share-based payment transactions.

1172706_14_ITEM9A_P0_S0	The Company maintains disclosure controls and procedures as defined in Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (the Exchange Act ), that are designed to ensure that information required to be disclosed by us in reports we file or submit under the Exchange Act is recorded, processed, summarized and reported within the time periods specified in the SEC s rules and forms, and that such information is accumulated and communicated to our management, including our Acting President, Chief Financial Officer, and Board of Directors, as appropriate, to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure.
1172706_14_ITEM9A_P0_S1	In designing and evaluating our disclosure controls and procedures, management recognizes that disclosure controls and procedures, no matter how well conceived and operated, can provide only reasonable assurance of achieving the desired objectives, and we necessarily are required to apply our judgment in evaluating the cost-benefit relationship of possible disclosure controls and procedures.
1172706_14_ITEM9A_P1_S0	Our management, including our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, evaluated the effectiveness of the design and operation of our disclosure controls and procedures as of December 31, 2013 and concluded that our disclosure controls and procedures were effective as of December 31, 2013.
1172706_14_ITEM9A_P2_S0	The Company s management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting as defined in Rule 13a-15(f) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
1172706_14_ITEM9A_P2_S1	The Company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with United States generally accepted accounting principles.
1172706_14_ITEM9A_P2_S2	Internal control over financial reporting includes policies and procedures that (i) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the Company; (ii) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with United States generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the Company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the Company; and (iii) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisitions, use or disposition of the Company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
1172706_14_ITEM9A_P3_S0	Management assessed the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2013.
1172706_14_ITEM9A_P3_S1	In making this assessment, management used the criteria set forth by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission ( COSO ) in Internal Control-Integrated Framework published in 1992.
1172706_14_ITEM9A_P3_S2	Based on this assessment, and on those criteria, management concluded that the Company s internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December 31, 2013.
1172706_14_ITEM9A_P4_S0	This annual report does not include an attestation report of the Company s registered public accounting firm regarding internal control over financial reporting.
1172706_14_ITEM9A_P4_S1	Management s report was not subject to attestation by the Company s registered public accounting firm pursuant to rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission that permit the Company to provide only management s report in this annual report.
1172706_14_ITEM9A_P5_S0	During the quarter ended December 31, 2013, there were no changes in the Company s internal control over financial reporting (as defined in Rule 13a-15(f) and 15d 15(f) under the Exchange Act) that has materially affected, or is reasonably likely to materially affect, the Company s internal control over financial reporting.

1172706_14_ITEM11_P0_S0	This Compensation Discussion and Analysis is intended to describe the material factors underlying the compensation policies and decisions of the Company with regard to compensation paid to our executive officers in 2012 and 2013.
1172706_14_ITEM11_P1_S0	The Compensation Committee oversees the Company s executive compensation in accordance with its Charter and recommends to the Board of Directors compensation for the named executive officers.
1172706_14_ITEM11_P1_S1	The Compensation Committee receives input and recommendations when requested from our executive officers.
1172706_14_ITEM11_P2_S0	Mr. Edmund King, our CEO and CFO, does not have a written employment agreement and works on a part-time basis for the Company.
1172706_14_ITEM11_P2_S1	Mr. King received no salary or other cash compensation during fiscal 2012 or 2013; however the Company charged $36,000 to operations for the value of his services in each of these years.
1172706_14_ITEM11_P2_S2	Ms. Henson (appointed as an Officer in 2011) received cash consulting fees of $49,500 in 2013.
1172706_14_ITEM11_P2_S3	In addition, Ms. Henson received Common stock grants totaling 35,000 shares for service in 2012.
1172706_14_ITEM11_P3_S0	Our compensation philosophy for our executive officers has been shaped by our lack of long-term financing and our severe shortage of operating capital.
1172706_14_ITEM11_P3_S1	Accordingly, our compensation decisions and particularly our approach to allocating compensation between cash and non-cash elements of the compensation package reflect our goal to preserve cash whenever possible.
1172706_14_ITEM11_P4_S0	In making our compensation decisions, we strive to be aware of the level of compensation which is paid to executive officers of various companies that we consider to be comparable to us in size.
1172706_14_ITEM11_P4_S1	Our goal is for the compensation paid to our named executive officers to be at or below the fiftieth percentile of the companies that we have identified as being comparable companies.
1172706_14_ITEM11_P5_S0	Mr. King did not receive any base salary in fiscal 2012 or 2013; however, an amount of $36,000 has been charged to operations and credited to additional paid in capital in each of these years.
1172706_14_ITEM11_P6_S0	No Options were granted in fiscal years 2012 or 2013.
1172706_14_ITEM11_P7_S0	Consistent with our philosophy to preserve cash, we have sought to limit perquisites.
1172706_14_ITEM11_P7_S1	Perquisites paid to our named executive officers are discussed as footnotes to the following Summary Compensation Table.
1172706_14_ITEM11_P8_S0	Our current policy for paying medical and dental insurance is not to pay insurance premiums.
1172706_14_ITEM11_P8_S1	Our policy is not to pay for life insurance, long-term and short-term disability insurances and accidental death and dismemberment insurance.
1172706_14_ITEM11_P8_S2	Our policy with regard to unused vacation for our executive group is to pay at the base salary rate for vacation not used during the calendar year of termination.
