1172706_16_ITEM8_P32_S1	To the extent it has been determined that the carrying value of goodwill or trademarks is not recoverable and is in excess of its fair value, an impairment loss is recognized.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P32_S2	No impairment loss adjustment was deemed necessary as of January 3, 2016 or December 28, 2014.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P33_S0	The Company follows ASC 740 Income Taxes for recording the provision for income taxes.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P34_S0	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are computed based upon the difference between the financial statement and income tax bases of assets and liabilities using the enacted marginal tax rate applicable when the related asset or liability is expected to be realized or settled.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P34_S1	Deferred income tax expenses or benefits are based on the changes in the asset or liability each period.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P34_S2	If available evidence suggests that it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized, a valuation allowance is required to reduce the deferred tax asset to the amount that is more likely than not to be realized.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P34_S3	Future changes in such valuation allowance are included in the provision for deferred income taxes in the period of change.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P35_S0	The tax effects from an uncertain tax position are recognized in the financial statements only if the position is more likely than not to be sustained on audit, based on the technical merits of the position.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P35_S1	The Company recognizes the financial statement benefit of a tax position only after determining that the relevant tax authority would more likely than not sustain the position following an audit.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P35_S2	For tax positions meeting the more likely than not threshold, the amount recognized in the financial statements is the largest benefit that has a greater than 50 percent likelihood of being realized upon ultimate settlement with the relevant tax authority.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P35_S3	The Company does not believe there is any uncertainty with respect to its tax positions which would result in a material change to the financial statements.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P36_S0	The Company files income tax returns in the United States as a C-Corporation, and in several state jurisdictions and in the United Kingdom.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P36_S1	The Company s subsidiary, Uniroyal, is a limited liability company (LLC) for federal and state income tax purposes and as such, its income, losses, and credits are allocated to its members.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P36_S2	Prior to November 10, 2014, as the previous owners, the sellers were the sole members and reported the allocations on their personal tax returns.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P36_S3	As a result, in the accompanying Consolidated Statements of Operations, there is no tax provision on its income prior to November 10, 2014.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P36_S4	After this date, Uniroyal s income is allocated entirely to UEPH as its sole member.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P36_S5	The Company then receives this income allocation as the sole member of UEPH less the dividends paid on the preferred units held by the former members of Uniroyal.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P37_S0	The Company s tax returns for tax years 2012 and thereafter are subject to examination by taxing authorities.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P37_S1	The Company records interest and penalties associated with uncertain tax positions related to these tax filings as interest expense.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P37_S2	For the years ended January 3, 2016 and December 28, 2014, the Company has recorded no expense for interest or penalties.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P38_S0	The Company recognizes all of its derivative instruments, which consist of interest rate swaps, as either assets or liabilities in the balance sheet at fair value.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P38_S1	The accounting for changes in the fair value of a derivative instrument depends on whether it has been designated and qualifies as part of a hedging relationship and further, whether the hedge is a cash flow hedge or a fair value hedge.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P39_S0	The Company uses interest rate swaps to manage interest rate risk on its variable interest rate long-term debt instruments.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P39_S1	The gain or loss on the effective portion of interest rate swaps treated as cash flow hedges is initially included as a component of other comprehensive income and is subsequently reclassified into earnings when interest on the related debt is paid.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P39_S2	The gain or loss on the portion of interest rate swaps that are not effective is treated as financial instruments and is included as a component of interest expense on the accompanying Consolidated Statements of Operations.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P39_S3	The Company did not have any interest rate swaps outstanding as of January 3, 2016.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P40_S0	The Company incurs foreign currency risk on sales and purchases denominated in other currencies, primarily the British Pound Sterling and the Euro.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P40_S1	Foreign currency exchange contracts are used by the Company principally to limit the exchange rate fluctuations of the Euro.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P40_S2	The Euro risk is partially limited due to natural cash flow offsets.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P40_S3	Currency exchange contracts are purchased for approximately 25% of the net risk.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P40_S4	These contracts are not designated as cash flow hedges for accounting purposes.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P40_S5	Changes in fair value of these contracts are reported in net earnings as part of other income and expense.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P41_S0	The Company s short term financial instruments consist of cash and cash equivalents, receivables, accounts payable and the line of credit.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P41_S1	The Company adjusts the carrying value of financial assets denominated in other currencies such as cash, receivables, accounts payable and the lines of credit using the appropriate exchange rates at the balance sheet date.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P41_S2	The Company believes that the carrying values of these short term financial instruments approximate their estimated fair values.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P42_S0	The fair value of the Company s long term debt is estimated based on current rates for similar instruments with the same remaining maturities.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P42_S1	In determining the current interest rates for similar instruments the Company takes into account its risk of nonperformance.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P43_S0	The Company believes that the carrying value of its long term debt approximates its estimated fair value.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P44_S0	The fair value of the Company s interest rate swaps is the estimated amounts that the Company would receive, or pay, to sell or transfer the swaps to a third party, taking into account current and future interest rates and the nonperformance risk of the Company and the counterparty.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P44_S1	At January 3, 2016 and December 28, 2014 the Company did not have any interest rate swaps.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P45_S0	The Company uses foreign currency exchange contracts which are recorded at their estimated fair values in the accompanying Consolidated Balance Sheets.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P45_S1	The fair values of the currency exchange contracts are based upon observable market transactions of spot and forward rates.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P46_S0	For the fiscal year ended January 3, 2016, there have been no changes in the application of valuation methods applied to similar assets and liabilities.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P47_S0	The Company follows accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America for measuring, reporting, and disclosing fair value.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P47_S1	These standards apply to all assets and liabilities that are measured, reported, and/or disclosed on a fair value basis.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P48_S0	Fair value is the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P48_S1	The fair value hierarchy ranks the quality and reliability of the information used to determine fair values.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P48_S2	Assets and liabilities measured, reported and/or disclosed at fair value will be classified and disclosed in one of the following three categories:
1172706_16_ITEM8_P49_S0	Inputs to the valuation methodology are unadjusted quoted market prices for identical assets in active markets that the Company has the ability to access.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P50_S0	Observable market based inputs or unobservable inputs that are corroborated by market data.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P50_S1	Inputs to the valuation methodology include:
1172706_16_ITEM8_P51_S0	inputs that are derived principally from or corroborated by observable market data by correlation or other means.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P52_S0	Unobservable inputs that are unobservable and not corroborated by market data.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P53_S0	The asset s or liability s fair value measurement level within the fair value hierarchy is based on the lowest level of any input that is significant to the fair value measurement.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P54_S0	Valuation techniques used need to maximize the use of observable inputs and minimize the use of unobservable inputs.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P55_S0	The financial position and results of operations of the Company s foreign subsidiaries are measured using the local currency as the functional currency.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P55_S1	Assets and liabilities of operations denominated in foreign currencies are translated into U.S. dollars at exchange rates in effect at the balance sheet date, while revenues and expenses are translated at the weighted average exchange rates during the year.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P55_S2	The resulting translation gains and losses on assets and liabilities are recorded in accumulated other comprehensive income (loss), and are excluded from net income until realized through a sale or liquidation of the investment.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P56_S0	The preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P56_S1	Actual results could differ from those estimates.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P57_S0	Revenue is generally recognized from product sales upon shipment to the customer or upon receipt by the customer in accordance with the agreed upon customer terms when title and risk of ownership have passed, the price to the buyer is fixed or determinable and collectability is reasonably assured.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P57_S1	Based on historical results and analysis, we estimate and calculate provisions for customer rebates and sales returns and allowances and record as an offset to revenue in the same period the related revenue is recognized.

1172706_16_ITEM8_P64_S1	Under ASU 2014-09 recognition of revenue occurs when a customer obtains control of promised goods or services in an amount that reflects the consideration to which the entity expects to be entitled in exchange for those goods or services.

1172706_16_ITEM8_P67_S0	On July 22, 2015, the Financial Accounting Standards Board issued a new standard ASU No. 2015-11, Simplifying the Measurement of Inventory .
1172706_16_ITEM8_P67_S1	The new standard requires entities to measure most inventory at the lower of cost and net realizable value, which is a change from the current guidance under which an entity must measure inventory at the lower of cost or market with market defined as replacement cost, net realizable value or net realizable value less a normal profit margin.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P67_S2	The ASU will not apply to inventories that are measured by using either the last-in, first-out (LIFO) method or the retail inventory method.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P67_S3	It will be effective for the Company on January 2, 2017.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P67_S4	The Company is in the process of determining what impact, if any, the adoption of this ASU will have on its financial position, results of operations and cash flows.

1172706_16_ITEM8_P69_S1	Under the new guidance, a lessee will be required to recognize assets and liabilities for leases with lease terms of more than 12 months.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P70_S0	Consistent with current Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP), the recognition, measurement, and presentation of expenses and cash flows arising from a lease by a lessee primarily will depend on its classification as a finance or operating lease.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P70_S1	However, unlike current GAAP which requires only capital leases to be recognized on the balance sheet the new ASU will require both types of leases to be recognized on the balance sheet.

1172706_16_ITEM8_P98_S0	The Company held derivative instruments, which consisted of interest rate swaps.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P98_S1	Accounting standards require that an entity recognize all derivative instruments as either assets or liabilities at fair value in the balance sheet.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P98_S2	Certain swaps do not meet the criteria of cash flow hedges under generally accepted accounting principles; these swaps are accounted for as derivatives not designated as hedging instruments with changes in the fair value of the interest rate swaps included in interest expense in the accompanying Consolidated Statements of Operations.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P99_S0	For derivative instruments that are designated and qualify as cash flow hedges, the effective portion of the gain or loss on the derivative instrument is reported as a component of other comprehensive income and reclassified into earnings in the same period or periods during which the hedged transaction affects earnings.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P99_S1	Gains and losses on the derivative instrument representing either hedge ineffectiveness or hedge components excluded from the assessment of effectiveness are recognized in current earnings.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P100_S0	The Company had an interest rate swap with a notional amount of $6,000,000 accounted for as an effective cash flow hedge.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P100_S1	The interest rate swap fixed the Company s one month LIBOR interest rate on the notional amounts at a rate of 1.25%.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P100_S2	The interest rate swap expired on July 30, 2014.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P100_S3	The Company did not have any interest rate swap outstanding at January 3, 2016 and December 28, 2014.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P101_S0	The effect of interest rate swaps designated as hedging instruments is reported in the Consolidated Statements of Comprehensive Income and Consolidated Statements of Stockholders Equity as follows:
1172706_16_ITEM8_P102_S0	The LIBOR swap rates are observable at commonly quoted intervals for the full terms of the interest rate swaps and therefore are considered Level 2 items.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P102_S1	As such, the Company s interest rate swap was considered a Level 2 item.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P103_S0	The preceding method described may produce a fair value calculation that may not be indicative of net realizable value or reflective of future fair values.
1172706_16_ITEM8_P103_S1	Furthermore, although the Company believes its valuation method is appropriate and consistent with other market participants, the use of different methodologies or assumptions to determine the fair value could result in a different fair value measurement at the reporting date.

1172706_16_ITEM9A_P0_S0	The Company maintains disclosure controls and procedures as defined in Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (the Exchange Act ), that are designed to ensure that information required to be disclosed by us in reports we file or submit under the Exchange Act is recorded, processed, summarized and reported within the time periods specified in the SEC s rules and forms, and that such information is accumulated and communicated to our management, including our Chief Executive Officer, Chief Financial Officer, and Board of Directors, as appropriate, to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure.
1172706_16_ITEM9A_P0_S1	In designing and evaluating our disclosure controls and procedures, management recognizes that disclosure controls and procedures, no matter how well conceived and operated, can provide only reasonable assurance of achieving the desired objectives, and we necessarily are required to apply our judgment in evaluating the cost-benefit relationship of possible disclosure controls and procedures.
1172706_16_ITEM9A_P1_S0	Our management, including our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, evaluated the effectiveness of the design and operation of our disclosure controls and procedures as of January 3, 2016 and concluded that our disclosure controls and procedures were effective as of January 3, 2016.
1172706_16_ITEM9A_P2_S0	The Company s management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting as defined in Rule 13a-15(f) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
1172706_16_ITEM9A_P2_S1	The Company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with United States generally accepted accounting principles.
1172706_16_ITEM9A_P2_S2	Internal control over financial reporting includes policies and procedures that (i) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the Company; (ii) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with United States generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the Company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the Company; and (iii) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisitions, use or disposition of the Company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
1172706_16_ITEM9A_P3_S0	Management assessed the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting as of January 3, 2016.
1172706_16_ITEM9A_P3_S1	In making this assessment, management used the criteria set forth by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission ( COSO ) in Internal Control-Integrated Framework published in 1992.
1172706_16_ITEM9A_P3_S2	Based on this assessment, and on those criteria, management concluded that the Company s internal control over financial reporting was effective as of January 3, 2016.
1172706_16_ITEM9A_P4_S0	This annual report does not include an attestation report of the Company s registered public accounting firm regarding internal control over financial reporting.
1172706_16_ITEM9A_P4_S1	Management s report was not subject to attestation by the Company s registered public accounting firm pursuant to rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission that permit the Company to provide only management s report in this annual report.

1172706_17_ITEM1_P0_S0	On November 10, 2014 Uniroyal Global Engineered Products, Inc. ( Uniroyal Global or the Company ) acquired all of the ownership interests in Uniroyal Engineered Products, LLC ( Uniroyal ), a U.S. manufacturer of textured coatings, and all of the ordinary common stock of Engineered Products Acquisition Limited ( EPAL, now known as Uniroyal Global (Europe) Limited), the holding company for Wardle Storeys (Group) Limited ( Wardle Storeys, now known as Uniroyal Global Limited), a European manufacturer of textured coatings and polymer films.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P0_S1	Management of the acquired entities was not altered in the acquisitions.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P1_S0	Uniroyal Global made the acquisition of Uniroyal through its newly formed subsidiary, UEP Holdings, LLC ( UEPH ), to which it contributed certain of its assets and liabilities as part of the organization of that subsidiary.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P1_S1	The aggregate purchase consideration paid for 100% of the outstanding equity of Uniroyal was preferred ownership interests issued by UEPH having an aggregate face value of $35 million.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P1_S2	In a separate transaction, Uniroyal Global also purchased EPAL for aggregate consideration of 100 shares of Uniroyal Global s Common Stock and Uniroyal Global s guaranty of outstanding EPAL preferred stock retained by the seller having a face value of 12,601,198 (approximately $20 million at closing).
1172706_17_ITEM1_P1_S3	Details of the acquisition are set forth in the Current Report on Form 8-K filed by the Company on November 10, 2014, which is incorporated herein by reference.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P2_S0	We are a manufacturer and seller of vinyl coated fabrics products that have various high performance characteristics and capabilities and derive our revenue principally through our subsidiaries Uniroyal and Uniroyal Global Limited.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P2_S1	Our coated fabrics products are durable, stain resistant, easily processed, cost-effective and better performing than traditional leather or fabric coverings.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P2_S2	Our products are frequently used in applications that require rigorous performance characteristics such as automotive and non-automotive transportation, certain indoor/outdoor furniture, commercial and hospitality seating, healthcare facilities and athletic equipment.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P2_S3	In the automotive industry our products are used primarily in seating, door panels, head and arm rests, security shades and trim components, including instrument panels, door casings, seating, gear lever and steering column gaiters, headliners and load space covers.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P2_S4	Non-automotive applications include outdoor seating for utility and sports vehicles, and sheeting used in medical, nuclear protection, personal protection, moisture barriers, pram and nursery, movie screen and decorative surface applications.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P3_S0	Our primary brands names include Naugahyde , BeautyGard , Flameblocker , Spirit Millennium , Ambla , Amblon , Velbex , Cirroflex , Plastolene and Vynide .
1172706_17_ITEM1_P4_S0	We are the successor to a long line of businesses that have manufactured vinyl coated fabrics.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P4_S1	Our best known brand, Naugahyde, is the product of many improvements on a rubber-coated fabric developed a century ago in Naugatuck, Connecticut.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P4_S2	We design, manufacture and market a wide selection of vinyl coated fabric products under a portfolio of recognized brand names.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P4_S3	We believe that our business has continued to be a leading supplier in its marketplace because of our ability to provide specialized materials with performance characteristics customized to the end-user specifications, complemented by technical and customer support for the use of our products in manufacturing.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P5_S0	Our vinyl coated fabrics products have undergone considerable evolution and today are distinguished by superior performance in a wide variety of applications as alternatives to leather, cloth and other synthetic fabric coverings.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P5_S1	Our standard product lines consist of more than 600 SKUs with combinations of colors, textures, patterns and other properties.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P5_S2	Our products are differentiated by unique protective top finishes, adhesive back coatings and transfer print capabilities.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P5_S3	Additional process capabilities include embossing grains and patterns, and rotogravure printing, which imparts character prints and non-registered prints, lamination and panel cutting.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P6_S0	Our vinyl coated fabrics products have various high performance characteristics and capabilities.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P6_S1	They are durable, stain resistant, easily processed, more cost-effective and better performing than traditional leather or fabric coverings.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P6_S2	Our products are frequently used in applications that require rigorous performance characteristics such as automotive and non-automotive transportation, certain indoor/outdoor furniture, commercial and hospitality seating, healthcare facilities and athletic equipment.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P7_S0	We manufacture materials in a wide range of colors and textures.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P7_S1	They can be hand or machine sewn, laminated to an underlying structure, thermoformed to cover various substrates or made into a variety of shapes for diverse end-uses.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P8_S0	We are a long-established supplier to the global automotive industry and manufacture products for interior trim components from floor to headliner which are produced to meet specific component production requirements such as cut and sew, vacuum forming/covering, compression molding, and high frequency welding.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P8_S1	Some products are supplied with micro perforations, which are necessary on most compression molding processes.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P8_S2	Materials can also be combined with polyurethane or polypropylene foam laminated by either flame or hot melt adhesive for seating, fascia and door applications.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P9_S0	The automotive sector represented approximately 64.9% of our total sales in 2016.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P9_S1	Our products are used primarily in the following automotive applications:
1172706_17_ITEM1_P10_S0	The non-automotive transportation sector represented 11.4% of our 2016 sales and primarily consisted of seating products for original equipment manufacturers of non-automotive and light truck vehicles in the following five categories:
1172706_17_ITEM1_P11_S0	The distribution market sector represented approximately 10.8% of our 2016 sales and consists primarily of sales of the standard Naugahyde and Ambla product lines to local furniture shops, smaller furniture manufacturers and companies serving the hospitality and automotive and marine aftermarkets for refurbishing and replacement.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P11_S1	The sales organization employed to service this market is a network of approximately 40 distributor locations.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P12_S0	The contract sector, which represented approximately 12.9% of our 2016 sales, includes contract furniture/upholstery, marine, healthcare, child care, and industrial equipment.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P13_S0	Products are developed and marketed based upon the performance characteristics required by end-users.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P13_S1	For example, for recreational products used outdoors, such as boats, personal watercraft, golf carts and snowmobiles, a product designed primarily for durability and weatherability is used.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P13_S2	We also manufacture a line of products called BeautyGard , with water-based topcoats that contain agents to protect against bacterial and fungal microorganisms and can withstand repeated cleaning, a necessity in the restaurant and health care industries.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P13_S3	These topcoats are environmentally friendlier than solvent-based topcoats.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P14_S0	The line is widely used in hospitals and other healthcare facilities.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P15_S0	Flame and smoke retardant vinyl coated fabrics are used for a variety of commercial and institutional furniture applications, including hospitals, restaurants and residential care centers and seats for school buses and aircraft.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P16_S0	We produce vinyl coated fabrics and laminated composites through a continuous cast manufacturing process.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P16_S1	The continuous cast method yields a material with a soft finish, deep grain pattern, wide temperature tolerance range and high malleability factor for thermoforming.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P16_S2	In addition, we possess plastisol-compounding capability, a variety of proprietary formulations and highly versatile finishing processes.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P16_S3	We believe that our products are differentiated in the market by unique protective topcoat finishes and adhesive back coats, as well as rotogravure printing, which imparts multiple features, character prints and non-registered prints.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P16_S4	We also have the in-house capability to perform transfer printing as well as micro-perforation, which provides product breathability.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P17_S0	We seek to ensure that every product fully meets customer requirements of specification, reliability and performance.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P18_S0	We believe that we maintain our market leadership position through a strong research and development effort that provides strong product development capability.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P18_S1	This yields enhanced product characteristics, lower cost of material combinations and new proprietary product formulations.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P18_S2	We estimate that approximately 12.1% of our sales relate to products developed to customer specifications.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P19_S0	Our Stoughton, Wisconsin facility achieved ISO 9001:2008 status in 1999 and has renewed it annually since then.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P20_S0	We hold no patents but maintain certain of our process technologies as trade secrets.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P21_S0	Products are developed and marketed based upon the performance characteristics required by end-users.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P21_S1	We currently serve customers world-wide with 18 full-time sales persons in offices in Sarasota, Florida, Nappanee, Indiana and Earby, Lancashire, two exclusive agents in Italy, and Turkey and an extensive distributor network in the U.S., the United Kingdom, Scandinavia, France, Germany and Hong Kong.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P21_S2	10.8% of our worldwide sales in 2016 were made through distributors.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P22_S0	The industrial business is supported mainly from stock and via a catalogue.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P23_S0	We maintain websites for our principal U.S. non-automotive products at www.naugahyde.com and for our global products at www.uniroyalglobal.co.uk and www.ambla.com .
1172706_17_ITEM1_P24_S0	We sell our safety sensor products directly to manufacturers, dealers and end users.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P24_S1	We have attended trade shows and have continued our relationships with our customer list, which comprises manufacturers, dealers and end users.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P24_S2	We also receive unsolicited orders by telephone, fax or the internet.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P24_S3	In addition, we have sought relationships with architectural engineering firms and municipalities that are implementing projects requiring parking barrier gates, such as municipal parking lots and airport reconstruction.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P24_S4	Although we have not maintained a full-time sales force for this business, we have engaged an outside consultant.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P25_S0	We compete primarily on the basis of style, color, product breadth and quality, as well as price and customer service.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P26_S0	The global vinyl coated fabrics market is highly fragmented.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P27_S0	The uses of vinyl coated fabrics include automotive, furniture, industrial, protective clothing, wall coverings, book coverings, non-automotive transportation and awnings and tents.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P28_S0	The following table sets forth product applications in the markets in which we actively compete domestically and our primary competitors in those markets.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P29_S0	The principal raw materials for our coated fabrics are casting paper, knit fabric, PVC plastic resins, pigments and plasticizers.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P29_S1	We have multiple sources for most of these materials.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P29_S2	We believe that in the few instances where we have a sole supplier we can re-engineer around the sole-sourced materials if necessary with minimal effort and cost.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P30_S0	The only customers that accounts for ten percent or more of our consolidated revenues are FXI, Inc. and Lear Corporation.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P30_S1	Our top 25 customers account for approximately 65.0% of our total global sales.

1172706_17_ITEM1_P33_S0	Most of our employees who are involved in the production process are located at manufacturing facilities in Stoughton, Wisconsin and Earby, England.

1172706_17_ITEM1_P37_S0	On March 1, 2001, Underwriters Laboratory (UL) implemented a new safety standard for the powered gate, door and window industry.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P37_S1	This rule, while not a governmental regulation, is considered an indication of reasonable safety for powered gates, doors and windows.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P38_S0	Manufacturers of gates and operators that rely upon UL certification or consider UL certification to be significant could require that our product be certified by UL.
1172706_17_ITEM1_P38_S1	The absence of UL certification could present a barrier to sales to potential customers.

1172706_17_ITEM7_P0_S0	We are a leading provider of manufactured vinyl coated fabrics.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P0_S1	Our best known brand, Naugahyde, is the product of many improvements on rubber-coated fabrics developed a century ago in Naugatuck, Connecticut.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P0_S2	We design, manufacture and market a wide selection of vinyl coated fabric products under a portfolio of recognized brand names.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P0_S3	We believe that our business has continued to be a leading supplier in its marketplace because of our ability to provide specialized materials with performance characteristics customized to the end-user specifications, complemented by technical and customer support for the use of our products in manufacturing.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P1_S0	Our products have undergone considerable evolution and today are distinguished by superior performance in a wide variety of applications as alternatives to leather, cloth and other synthetic fabric coverings.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P1_S1	Our standard product lines consist of more than 600 SKUs with combinations of colors, textures, patterns and other properties.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P1_S2	Our products are differentiated by unique protective top finishes, adhesive back coatings and transfer print capabilities.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P1_S3	Additional process capabilities include embossing grains and patterns, and rotogravure printing, which imparts character prints and non-registered prints, lamination and panel cutting.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P2_S0	Our vinyl coated fabrics products have various high performance characteristics and capabilities.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P2_S1	They are durable, stain resistant, easily processed, more cost-effective and better performing than traditional leather or fabric coverings.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P2_S2	Our products are frequently used in applications that require rigorous performance characteristics such as automotive and non-automotive transportation, certain indoor/outdoor furniture, commercial and hospitality seating, healthcare facilities and athletic equipment.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P2_S3	Materials that we manufacture come in a wide range of colors and textures and can be hand or machine sewn, laminated to an underlying structure, thermoformed to cover various substrates or made into a variety of shapes for diverse end-uses.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P2_S4	We are a long-established supplier to the global automotive industry and manufacture products for interior soft trim components from floor to headliner which are produced to meet specific component production requirements such as cut and sew, vacuum forming/covering, compression molding, and high frequency welding.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P2_S5	Some products are supplied with micro perforations, which are necessary on most compression molding processes.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P2_S6	Materials can also be combined with polyurethane or polypropylene foam laminated with either flame or hot melt adhesive for seating, fascia and door applications.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P3_S0	Products are developed and marketed based upon the performance characteristics required by end-users.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P3_S1	For example, for recreational products used outdoors, such as boats, personal watercraft, golf carts and snowmobiles, a product designed primarily for water-based durability and weatherability is used.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P3_S2	We also manufacture a line of products with our proprietary BeautyGard topcoats that contain agents to protect against staining and bacterial and fungal micro-organisms and can withstand repeated cleaning, a necessity in the restaurant and health care industries.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P3_S3	These topcoats are environmentally friendlier than solvent-based topcoats.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P4_S0	The line is widely used in hospitals and other healthcare facilities.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P5_S0	Flame and smoke retardant vinyl coated fabrics are used for a variety of commercial and institutional furniture applications, including hospitals, restaurants and residential care centers and seats for school busses and aircraft.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P6_S0	We currently conduct our operations in manufacturing facilities that are located in Stoughton, Wisconsin and Earby, England.

1172706_17_ITEM7_P10_S4	Since the Pound Sterling exchange rate change also reduced the fixed expenses, the overall effect on net income was a positive amount of approximately $387,000 for the year ended January 1, 2017 compared to the year ended January 3, 2016.

1172706_17_ITEM7_P33_S0	The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission ("SEC") requires companies to provide additional disclosure and commentary on their most critical accounting policies.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P33_S1	The SEC has defined the most critical accounting policies as the ones that are most important to the portrayal of a company's financial condition and operating results, and requires management to make its most significant estimates and judgments in the preparation of its consolidated financial statements.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P33_S2	On an on-going basis, we evaluate our estimates and assumptions based upon historical experience and various other factors and circumstances.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P33_S3	Management believes that our estimates and assumptions are reasonable under the circumstances; however, actual results may vary from these estimates and assumptions under different future circumstances.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P33_S4	Our critical accounting policies are described below.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P34_S0	Revenue is generally recognized from product sales upon shipment to the customer or upon receipt by the customer in accordance with the agreed upon customer terms when title and risk of ownership have passed, the price to the buyer is fixed or determinable and collectability is reasonably assured.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P34_S1	Based on historical results and analysis, we estimate and calculate provisions for customer rebates and sales returns and allowances and record as an offset to revenue in the same period the related revenue is recognized.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P35_S0	On an ongoing basis, we evaluate the accounts receivable based on individual customer circumstances, historical write-offs and collections, and current industry and customer credit conditions, and adjust the allowance for doubtful accounts accordingly.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P36_S0	Our policy regarding write-offs and collection efforts varies based on individual customer circumstances.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P37_S0	Past due accounts receivable are determined based on individual customer credit terms.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P38_S0	We value inventory at the lower of cost using the first-in, first-out (FIFO) method, or market.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P38_S1	We assess the recoverability of inventory and record a provision for obsolescence based upon specifically identified, discontinued, or obsolete items and a percentage of quantities on hand compared with historical and forecasted usage and sales levels.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P38_S2	These assessments, which require management s judgments and estimates, reduce inventories to their estimated net realizable value.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P39_S0	Long-lived assets consist of goodwill, identifiable intangible assets, trademarks, and property and equipment.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P39_S1	We have deemed that our trademarks have indefinite useful lives and are not amortized unless we determine their useful lives are no longer indefinite.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P39_S2	Other intangible assets and property and equipment, excluding goodwill, are amortized using the straight-line method over their estimated useful life.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P40_S0	We review long-lived assets, including property, equipment, and intangible assets, for impairment whenever events or changes in business circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of an asset may not be fully recoverable.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P40_S1	An impairment loss would be recognized when the estimated future cash flows from the use of the asset are less than the carrying amount of that asset.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P41_S0	The Company files income tax returns in the United States as a C-Corporation, and in several state jurisdictions and in the United Kingdom.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P41_S1	The Company s subsidiary, Uniroyal, is a limited liability company (LLC) for federal and state income tax purposes and as such, its income, losses, and credits are allocated to its members.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P41_S2	Prior to November 10, 2014, as the previous owners, the sellers were the sole members and reported the allocations on their personal tax returns.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P41_S3	As a result, there was no tax provision on its income prior to November 10, 2014.

1172706_17_ITEM7_P42_S1	Uniroyal s post-acquisition taxable income is allocated entirely to UEPH as its sole member and since it is a pass-through entity, this income less the dividends paid to the sellers of Uniroyal is reported on the Company s tax return.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P42_S2	The taxable income applicable to the dividends for the preferred ownership interests is reported to the sellers who report it on their respective individual tax returns.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P43_S0	We follow ASC 740 Income Taxes for recording the provision for income taxes.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P44_S0	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are computed based upon the difference between the financial statement and income tax basis of assets and liabilities using the enacted marginal tax rate applicable when the related asset or liability is expected to be realized or settled.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P44_S1	Deferred income tax expenses or benefits are based on the changes in the asset or liability each period.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P44_S2	If available evidence suggests that it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized, a valuation allowance is required to reduce the deferred tax asset to the amount that is more likely than not to be realized.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P44_S3	Future changes in such valuation allowance would be included in the provision for deferred income taxes in the period of change.

1172706_17_ITEM7_P55_S1	The new standard requires entities to measure most inventory at the lower of cost and net realizable value, which is a change from the current guidance under which an entity must measure inventory at the lower of cost or market with market defined as replacement cost, net realizable value or net realizable value less a normal profit margin.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P55_S2	The ASU will not apply to inventories that are measured by using either the last-in, first-out (LIFO) method or the retail inventory method.

1172706_17_ITEM7_P57_S1	Under the new guidance, a lessee will be required to recognize assets and liabilities for leases with lease terms of more than 12 months.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P58_S0	Consistent with current Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP), the recognition, measurement, and presentation of expenses and cash flows arising from a lease by a lessee primarily will depend on its classification as a finance or operating lease.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P58_S1	However, unlike current GAAP which requires only capital leases to be recognized on the balance sheet, the new ASU will require both types of leases to be recognized on the balance sheet.
1172706_17_ITEM7_P58_S2	It will be effective for the Company on December 31, 2018.

1172706_17_ITEM8_P40_S0	The Company follows accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America for measuring, reporting, and disclosing fair value.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P40_S1	These standards apply to all assets and liabilities that are measured, reported, and/or disclosed on a fair value basis.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P41_S0	Fair value is the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P41_S1	The fair value hierarchy ranks the quality and reliability of the information used to determine fair values.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P41_S2	Assets and liabilities measured, reported and/or disclosed at fair value will be classified and disclosed in one of the following three categories:
1172706_17_ITEM8_P42_S0	Inputs to the valuation methodology are unadjusted quoted market prices for identical assets in active markets that the Company has the ability to access.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P43_S0	Observable market based inputs or unobservable inputs that are corroborated by market data.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P43_S1	Inputs to the valuation methodology include:
1172706_17_ITEM8_P44_S0	inputs that are derived principally from or corroborated by observable market data by correlation or other means.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P45_S0	Unobservable inputs that are unobservable and not corroborated by market data.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P46_S0	The asset s or liability s fair value measurement level within the fair value hierarchy is based on the lowest level of any input that is significant to the fair value measurement.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P47_S0	Valuation techniques used need to maximize the use of observable inputs and minimize the use of unobservable inputs.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P48_S0	The financial position and results of operations of the Company s foreign subsidiaries are measured using the local currency as the functional currency.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P48_S1	Assets and liabilities of operations denominated in foreign currencies are translated into U.S. dollars at exchange rates in effect at the balance sheet date, while the capital accounts are translated at the historical rate for the date they were recognized.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P48_S2	Revenues and expenses are translated at the weighted average exchange rates during the year.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P48_S3	The resulting translation gains and losses on assets and liabilities are recorded in accumulated other comprehensive income (loss), and are excluded from net income until realized through a sale or liquidation of the investment.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P49_S0	The preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P49_S1	Actual results could differ from those estimates.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P50_S0	Revenue is generally recognized from product sales upon shipment to the customer or upon receipt by the customer in accordance with the agreed upon customer terms when title and risk of ownership have passed, the price to the buyer is fixed or determinable and collectability is reasonably assured.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P50_S1	Based on historical results and analysis, we estimate and calculate provisions for customer rebates and sales returns and allowances and record these estimated amounts as an offset to revenue in the same period the related revenue is recognized.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P51_S0	Shipping and handling costs charged to customers and the costs incurred by the Company are netted.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P51_S1	Shipping and handling costs incurred by the Company are included in cost of goods sold .
1172706_17_ITEM8_P52_S0	The Company warrants that the materials and workmanship of its products will meet customer specifications.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P52_S1	The Company estimates its accrued warranty expenses based upon prior warranty claims experience.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P52_S2	Accrued warranty expenses were not material as of January 1, 2017 and January 3, 2016.

1172706_17_ITEM8_P60_S0	On July 22, 2015, the Financial Accounting Standards Board issued a new standard ASU No. 2015-11, Simplifying the Measurement of Inventory .
1172706_17_ITEM8_P60_S1	The new standard requires entities to measure most inventory at the lower of cost and net realizable value, which is a change from the current guidance under which an entity must measure inventory at the lower of cost or market with market defined as replacement cost, net realizable value or net realizable value less a normal profit margin.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P60_S2	The ASU will not apply to inventories that are measured by using either the last-in, first-out (LIFO) method or the retail inventory method.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P60_S3	It will be effective for the Company on January 2, 2017.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P60_S4	The adoption of this standard for the year ending December 31, 2017 will not have a significant effect on its consolidated financial position, results of operations and cash flows. .

1172706_17_ITEM8_P62_S0	On February 25 , 2016 the Financial Accounting Standards Board issued a new standard ASU No. 2016 - 02, Leases .
1172706_17_ITEM8_P62_S1	Under the new guidance, a lessee will be required to recognize assets and liabilities for leases with lease terms of more than 12 months.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P63_S0	Consistent with current Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP), the recognition, measurement, and presentation of expenses and cash flows arising from a lease by a lessee primarily will depend on its classification as a finance or operating lease.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P63_S1	However, unlike current GAAP which requires only capital leases to be recognized on the balance sheet the new ASU will require both types of leases to be recognized on the balance sheet.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P63_S2	It will be effective for the Company on December 31, 2018.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P63_S3	The Company is currently evaluating the effects this standard will have, if any, on its consolidated financial position, results of operations and cash flows together with evaluating the adoption date.

1172706_17_ITEM8_P117_S2	Each of the UEP Holdings Series A and Series B preferred units have an issue price of $100 per unit or a total face value of $20,000,000 and $15,000,000, respectively.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P117_S3	The Series UEPH A preferred units are entitled to a preferred return of an amount per annum equal to five percent (5.00%) of the issue price of such UEPH Series A preferred unit.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P117_S4	The UEPH Series B preferred units are entitled to a preferred return of an amount per annum equal to five and one half percent (5.50%) of the issue price of such UEPH Series B preferred unit, increasing by one half percent (0.50%) on the first anniversary of the effective date and by an additional one half percent (0.50%) on each successive anniversary of the effective date thereafter, up to a maximum of eight percent (8.00%) on the fifth anniversary of the effective date.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P117_S5	As of January 1, 2017, the preferred return percentage of the Series UEPH B preferred units is 6.5%.

1172706_17_ITEM8_P118_S1	As part of the transaction, 50 shares of the UGEL common stock held by the seller had been converted and reclassified as preferred shares.
1172706_17_ITEM8_P118_S2	These preferred shares were entitled to a fixed cumulative preferential dividend of 625,912 per annum payable quarterly (approximately $1,000,000 at the date of the transaction).

1172706_17_ITEM9A_P0_S0	The Company maintains disclosure controls and procedures as defined in Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (the Exchange Act ), that are designed to ensure that information required to be disclosed by us in reports we file or submit under the Exchange Act is recorded, processed, summarized and reported within the time periods specified in the SEC s rules and forms, and that such information is accumulated and communicated to our management, including our Chief Executive Officer, Chief Financial Officer, and Board of Directors, as appropriate, to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure.
1172706_17_ITEM9A_P0_S1	In designing and evaluating our disclosure controls and procedures, management recognizes that disclosure controls and procedures, no matter how well conceived and operated, can provide only reasonable assurance of achieving the desired objectives, and we necessarily are required to apply our judgment in evaluating the cost-benefit relationship of possible disclosure controls and procedures.
1172706_17_ITEM9A_P1_S0	Our management, including our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, evaluated the effectiveness of the design and operation of our disclosure controls and procedures as of January 1, 2017 and concluded that our disclosure controls and procedures were effective as of January 1, 2017.
1172706_17_ITEM9A_P2_S0	The Company s management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting as defined in Rule 13a-15(f) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
1172706_17_ITEM9A_P2_S1	The Company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with United States generally accepted accounting principles.
1172706_17_ITEM9A_P2_S2	Internal control over financial reporting includes policies and procedures that (i) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the Company; (ii) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with United States generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the Company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the Company; and (iii) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisitions, use or disposition of the Company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
1172706_17_ITEM9A_P3_S0	Management assessed the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting as of January 1, 2017.
1172706_17_ITEM9A_P3_S1	In making this assessment, management used the criteria set forth by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission ( COSO ) in Internal Control-Integrated Framework published in 2013.
1172706_17_ITEM9A_P3_S2	Based on this assessment, and on those criteria, management concluded that the Company s internal control over financial reporting was effective as of January 1, 2017.
1172706_17_ITEM9A_P4_S0	This annual report does not include an attestation report of the Company s registered public accounting firm regarding internal control over financial reporting.
1172706_17_ITEM9A_P4_S1	Management s report was not subject to attestation by the Company s registered public accounting firm pursuant to rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission that permit the Company to provide only management s report in this annual report.
1172706_17_ITEM9A_P5_S0	During the year ended January 1, 2017, there were no changes in the Company s internal control over financial reporting (as defined in Rule 13a-15(f) and 15d 15(f) under the Exchange Act) that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, the Company s internal control over financial reporting.

1172706_18_ITEM1_P0_S0	On November 10, 2014, Uniroyal Global Engineered Products, Inc.
1172706_18_ITEM1_P0_S1	( Uniroyal Global or the Company ) acquired all of the ownership interests in Uniroyal Engineered Products, LLC ( Uniroyal ), a U.S. manufacturer of textured coatings, and all of the ordinary common stock of Engineered Products Acquisition Limited ( EPAL , now known as Uniroyal Global (Europe) Limited,) ( UGEL ), the holding company for Wardle Storeys (Earby) Limited ( Wardle Storeys, now known as Uniroyal Global Limited), a European manufacturer of textured coatings and polymer films.
1172706_18_ITEM1_P0_S2	Management of the acquired entities was not altered in the acquisitions.
1172706_18_ITEM1_P1_S0	Uniroyal Global made the acquisition of Uniroyal through a newly formed subsidiary, UEP Holdings, LLC ( UEPH ), to which it contributed certain of its assets and liabilities as part of the organization of that subsidiary.
1172706_18_ITEM1_P1_S1	The aggregate purchase consideration paid for 100% of the outstanding equity of Uniroyal was preferred ownership interests issued by UEPH having an aggregate face value of $35 million.
1172706_18_ITEM1_P1_S2	In a separate transaction, Uniroyal Global also purchased UGEL for aggregate consideration of 100 shares of Uniroyal Global s Common Stock and Uniroyal Global s guaranty of outstanding UGEP preferred stock retained by the seller having a face value of 12,518,240 (approximately $20 million at closing).
1172706_18_ITEM1_P2_S0	We are a manufacturer and seller of vinyl coated fabrics products that have excellent high performance characteristics and capabilities and derive our revenue principally through our subsidiaries Uniroyal and Uniroyal Global Limited.
1172706_18_ITEM1_P2_S1	Our coated fabrics products are durable, stain resistant, easily processed, cost-effective and better performing than traditional leather or fabric coverings.
1172706_18_ITEM1_P2_S2	Our products are frequently used in applications that require rigorous performance characteristics such as automotive and non-automotive transportation, certain indoor/outdoor furniture, commercial and hospitality seating, healthcare facilities and athletic equipment.
1172706_18_ITEM1_P2_S3	In the automotive industry our products are used primarily in seating, door panels, head and arm rests, security shades and trim components, including instrument panels, door casings, seating, gear lever and steering column gaiters, headliners and load space covers.
1172706_18_ITEM1_P2_S4	Non-automotive applications include outdoor seating for utility and sports vehicles, and sheeting used in medical and toxic hazard protection, personal protection, moisture barriers, pram and nursery equipment, movie screen and decorative surface applications.
1172706_18_ITEM1_P3_S0	Our primary brands names include Naugahyde , BeautyGard , Flame Blocker , Spirit Millennium , Ambla , Amblon , Velbex , Cirroflex , Plastolene and Vynide .
1172706_18_ITEM1_P4_S0	We are the successor to a long line of businesses that have manufactured vinyl coated fabrics.
1172706_18_ITEM1_P4_S1	Our best known brand, Naugahyde, is the product of many improvements on an original rubber-coated fabric developed a century ago in Naugatuck, Connecticut.
1172706_18_ITEM1_P4_S2	We design, manufacture and market a wide selection of vinyl coated fabric products under a portfolio of recognized brand names.
1172706_18_ITEM1_P4_S3	We believe that our business has continued to be a leading supplier in its marketplace because of our ability to provide specialized materials with high performance characteristics often customized to the end-user specifications and complemented by comprehensive technical and customer support.
1172706_18_ITEM1_P5_S0	Our vinyl coated fabrics products have undergone considerable evolution and today are distinguished by superior performance in a wide variety of applications as alternatives to leather, cloth and other synthetic fabric coverings.
1172706_18_ITEM1_P5_S1	Our standard product lines consist of more than 600 SKUs with combinations of colors, textures, patterns and other properties.
1172706_18_ITEM1_P5_S2	Our products are differentiated by unique protective top finishes and surface print capabilities.
1172706_18_ITEM1_P5_S3	Additional process capabilities include embossing grains and patterns, and rotogravure and registered printing, which imparts five color character prints as well as non-registered prints, lamination and panel cutting.
1172706_18_ITEM1_P6_S0	Our vinyl coated fabrics products have various high performance characteristics and capabilities.
1172706_18_ITEM1_P6_S1	They are durable, stain resistant, easily processed, more cost-effective and better performing than traditional leather or fabric coverings.
1172706_18_ITEM1_P6_S2	Our products are frequently used in applications that require rigorous performance characteristics such as automotive and non-automotive transportation, certain indoor/outdoor furniture, commercial and hospitality seating, healthcare facilities and athletic equipment.
1172706_18_ITEM1_P7_S0	We manufacture materials in a wide range of colors and textures.
1172706_18_ITEM1_P7_S1	They can be hand or machine sewn, laminated to an underlying structure, thermoformed to cover various substrates or made into a variety of shapes for diverse end-uses.
1172706_18_ITEM1_P8_S0	We are a long-established supplier to the global automotive industry and manufacture products for interior trim components from floor to headliner which are produced to meet specific component production requirements such as cut and sew, vacuum forming/covering, compression molding, and high frequency welding.
1172706_18_ITEM1_P8_S1	Some products are supplied with micro perforations, which are necessary on most compression molding processes.
1172706_18_ITEM1_P8_S2	Materials can also be combined with polyurethane or polypropylene and foam laminated by either flame or hot melt adhesive for seating, fascia and door applications.

1172706_18_ITEM1_P13_S1	For example, for recreational products used outdoors, such as boats, personal watercraft, golf carts and snowmobiles, a product designed primarily for durability and weatherability is used.

1172706_18_ITEM1_P16_S0	We produce vinyl coated fabrics and laminated composites through a continuous cast or spread coating manufacturing process.
1172706_18_ITEM1_P16_S1	The continuous cast method yields a material with a soft finish, deep grain pattern, wide temperature tolerance range and high malleability factor for thermoforming.
1172706_18_ITEM1_P16_S2	In addition, we possess plastisol-compounding capability, a variety of proprietary formulations and highly versatile finishing processes.
1172706_18_ITEM1_P16_S3	We believe that our products are differentiated in the market by unique protective topcoat finishes and adhesive back coats, as well as five color register and rotogravure printing, which imparts multiple features, character prints and non-registered prints.
1172706_18_ITEM1_P16_S4	We also have the in-house capability to perform transfer printing as well as micro-perforation, which provides product breathability.

1172706_18_ITEM7_P14_S0	The following table sets forth, for the year ended December 31, 2017 ( year ended 2017 ) and January 1, 2017 ( year ended 2016 ), certain operations data including their respective percentage of net sales:
1172706_18_ITEM7_P15_S0	Total revenue for the year ended 2017 decreased $2,239,218 or 2.2% to $98,138,060 from $100,377,278 for the year ended 2016.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P15_S1	Automotive sales for year-end 2017 decreased 1.5% compared to year-end 2016 as the increase in sales of several new programs in the European market was offset by a decline in the U.S. as automotive manufacturers adjusted their production due to a softening in the U.S. market.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P15_S2	Many of the U.S. automotive manufacturers idled production lines or entire assembly plants for multiple weeks to reduce inventories.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P15_S3	Industrial sales for the year-end 2017 were down 3.7% compared to the prior year period.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P15_S4	Contributing to the decline was the net currency effect of the exchange rate change of approximately $552,000.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P15_S5	Without the effect of the exchange rate change, total revenue would have only decreased by 1.7%.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P16_S0	Total gross profit for the year ended 2017 decreased $4,450,282 or 19.5% to $18,411,680 from $22,861,962 for the year ended 2016.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P16_S1	The gross profit percentage was 18.8% of sales for year-end 2017 compared to 22.8% for year-end 2016.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P16_S2	Gross profit was negatively impacted by rising raw material prices, unfavorable material usage variances and operating inefficiencies resulting from newly awarded automotive platforms ramping up in Europe.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P16_S3	The decrease was partially offset by a positive net currency effect of $422,000.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P16_S4	To offset raw material price increases, the Company increased prices in December in several of its markets.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P17_S0	Selling expenses for the year ended 2017 increased $35,020 or 0.7% to $5,113,726 from $5,078,706 for the year ended 2016.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P17_S1	The increase was principally attributable to an increase in commissions from higher European automotive sales.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P17_S2	The increase was partially offset by the net currency effect of $49,000.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P18_S0	General and administrative expenses for the year ended 2017 decreased $1,196,527 or 14.9% to $6,812,448 from $8,008,975 for the year ended 2016.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P18_S1	This decrease was a result of cost reduction programs which lowered employee costs, professional fees and other administrative expenses for year-end 2017 compared to year-end 2016.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P18_S2	Also contributing to the decrease was the net currency effect of $125,000.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P19_S0	Research and development expenses for the year ended 2017 increased $213,055 or 12.3% to $1,940,671 from $1,727,616 for the year ended 2016.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P19_S1	The increase resulted from additional staffing and increased expenditures for new product development.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P19_S2	This was partially offset by the net currency effect of the exchange rate change of $38,000.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P20_S0	Operating income for the year ended 2017 decreased $3,501,830 or 43.5% to $4,544,835 from $8,046,665 for the year ended 2016.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P20_S1	The operating income percentage was 4.6% of sales for year-end 2017 compared to 8.0% for year-end 2016.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P20_S2	Operating income decreased primarily from the decrease in gross profit.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P20_S3	This was partially offset by the reduction in operating expenses for year-end 2017 compared to 2016 and a positive net currency effect of $634,000.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P21_S0	Interest expense for the year ended 2017 increased $38,599 or 2.4% to $1,654,719 from $1,616,120 for the year ended 2016.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P21_S1	The increase was primarily due to new capital leases for equipment purchases and higher interest rates on LIBOR and prime during year-end 2017 partially offset by debt repayments compared to year-end 2016.

1172706_18_ITEM7_P38_S0	The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission ("SEC") requires companies to provide additional disclosure and commentary on their most critical accounting policies.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P38_S1	The SEC has defined the most critical accounting policies as the ones that are most important to the portrayal of a company's financial condition and operating results, and requires management to make its most significant estimates and judgments in the preparation of its consolidated financial statements.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P38_S2	On an on-going basis, we evaluate our estimates and assumptions based upon historical experience and various other factors and circumstances.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P38_S3	Management believes that our estimates and assumptions are reasonable under the circumstances; however, actual results may vary from these estimates and assumptions under different future circumstances.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P38_S4	Our critical accounting policies are described below.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P39_S0	Revenue is generally recognized from product sales upon shipment to the customer or upon receipt by the customer in accordance with the agreed upon customer terms when title and risk of ownership have passed, the price to the buyer is fixed or determinable and collectability is reasonably assured.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P39_S1	Based on historical results and analysis, we estimate and calculate provisions for customer rebates and sales returns and allowances and record these estimated amounts as an offset to revenue in the same period the related revenue is recognized.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P40_S0	On an ongoing basis, we evaluate our accounts receivable based on individual customer circumstances, historical write-offs and collections, and current industry and customer credit conditions, and adjust the allowance for doubtful accounts accordingly.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P40_S1	Our policy regarding write-offs and collection efforts varies based on individual customer circumstances.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P41_S0	Past due accounts receivable are determined based on individual customer credit terms.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P42_S0	We value inventory at the lower of cost using the first-in, first-out (FIFO) method, or market.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P42_S1	We assess the recoverability of inventory and record a provision for obsolescence based upon specifically identified, discontinued, or obsolete items and a percentage of quantities on hand compared with historical and forecasted usage and sales levels.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P42_S2	These assessments, which require management s judgments and estimates, reduce inventories to their estimated net realizable value.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P43_S0	Long-lived assets consist of goodwill, identifiable intangible assets, trademarks, and property and equipment.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P43_S1	We have deemed that our trademarks have indefinite useful lives and are not amortized unless we determine their useful lives are no longer indefinite.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P43_S2	Other intangible assets, excluding goodwill, and property and equipment are amortized using the straight-line method over their estimated useful life.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P44_S0	We review long-lived assets, including property, equipment, and intangible assets, for impairment whenever events or changes in business circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of an asset may not be fully recoverable.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P44_S1	An impairment loss would be recognized when the estimated future cash flows from the use of the asset are less than the carrying amount of that asset.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P45_S0	The Company files income tax returns in the United States as a C-Corporation, and in several state jurisdictions and in the United Kingdom.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P45_S1	The Company s subsidiary, Uniroyal, is a limited liability company (LLC) for federal and state income tax purposes and as such, its income, losses, and credits are allocated to its members.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P45_S2	The Company made the acquisition of Uniroyal through UEPH, a limited liability company, which issued preferred ownership interests to the sellers that provide for quarterly dividends.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P45_S3	Uniroyal s taxable income is allocated entirely to UEPH as its sole member and since it is a pass-through entity, this income less the dividends paid to the sellers of Uniroyal is reported on the Company s tax return.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P45_S4	The taxable income applicable to the dividends for the preferred ownership interests is reported to the sellers who report it on their respective individual tax returns.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P46_S0	We follow ASC 740 Income Taxes for recording the provision for income taxes.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P47_S0	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are computed based upon the difference between the financial statement and income tax basis of assets and liabilities (temporary differences) using the enacted marginal tax rate applicable when the related asset or liability is expected to be realized or settled.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P47_S1	As of December 31, 2017, the Company s U.S. deferred tax assets decreased to $3,167,092 due to a lower marginal tax rate to be applied to these assets.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P47_S2	The marginal tax rate was reduced by the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P48_S0	Deferred income tax expenses or benefits are based on the changes in the asset or liability each period.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P48_S1	If available evidence suggests that it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized, a valuation allowance is required to reduce the deferred tax asset to the amount that is more likely than not to be realized.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P48_S2	Future changes in such valuation allowance would be included in the provision for deferred income taxes in the period of change.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P49_S0	We have a federal net operating loss carryforward of approximately $16 million as of December 31, 2017, which expires in years beginning 2021 through 2034.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P49_S1	As a result of these loss carryforwards, we have deferred tax assets in the amount of $3,167,092.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P49_S2	Based on management s review at December 31, 2017 and January 1, 2017, it was determined that a valuation allowance was not required since it was more likely than not that the deferred tax asset would be realized.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P50_S0	The financial position and results of operations of our foreign subsidiaries are measured using the local currency as the functional currency.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P50_S1	Assets and liabilities of operations denominated in foreign currencies are translated into U.S. dollars at exchange rates in effect at the balance sheet date, while the capital accounts are translated at the historical rate for the date they were recognized.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P50_S2	Revenues and expenses are translated at the weighted average exchange rates during the year.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P50_S3	The resulting translation gains and losses on assets and liabilities are recorded in accumulated other comprehensive loss, and are excluded from net income until realized through a sale or liquidation of the investment.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P50_S4	Transaction gains and losses generated from the remeasurement of assets and liabilities denominated in currencies other than the functional currency of our foreign operations are included in Other Expense in the accompanying Consolidated Statements of Operations.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P51_S0	Our short-term financial instruments consist of cash and cash equivalents, accounts receivable, accounts payable and lines of credit.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P51_S1	We adjust the carrying value of financial instruments denominated in other currencies such as cash, accounts receivable, accounts payable and lines of credit using the appropriate exchange rates at the balance sheet date.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P51_S2	We believe that the carrying values of these short-term financial instruments approximate their estimated fair values.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P52_S0	The fair value of our long-term debt is estimated based on current rates for similar instruments with the same remaining maturities.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P53_S0	In determining the current interest rates for similar instruments, we take into account its risk of nonperformance.
1172706_18_ITEM7_P53_S1	We believe that the carrying value of our long-term debt approximates its estimated fair value.
